You can’t lose life from snow sources.
When you cast a red spell, creatures you control gain menace until end of turn.
Whenever an opponent casts a spell during your turn, Freyalise the Fire Mage deals 2 damage to them.
flavor: “I learned fire in a land of frost. Nothing warms you faster than refusing to die.”
lore: Freyalise’s early training under Clan Ruby forged her into a rare spark of heat in a world locked beneath snow. Her magic struck with unnerving precision, punishing any spell flung at her and emboldening every ally who fought beside her. Even before ascension, she carried herself like someone the winter could wound—but never claim.
art: Freyalise stands against the windswept cliffs of Storgard, her posture calm yet unmistakably commanding. Her cloak stirs like rising flame, and the fading sun paints her presence with a warmth the frozen land tries—and fails to deny.

name: Freyalise, Fyndhorn Goddess
rules:
+1: Target land becomes a 3/3 green Elemental creature with vigilance and trample until your next turn. It’s still a land.
-2: Reveal the top four cards of your library. You may put a creature card and a land card from among them into your hand.
-7: Each player sacrifices all permanents. For each creature sacrificed this way, its controller may put a basic land into play tapped.
flavor: “The forest never needed my command—it only needed my voice loud enough to answer the cold.”
lore: As worship of her spread among elves and druids, Freyalise wove her power through every frozen glade, urging the land to stir and defend itself. Elemental guardians rose at her gesture, and with each act of sacrifice she guided her people to reclaim what the cold had stolen. Her reign was not gentle, but it was fiercely protective—a living pact between the goddess and her wilderness.
art: Freyalise moves through the emerald dim of Fyndhorn, the cold parting around her like a veil. Her poise carries the quiet authority of someone entirely at home in her strength, the forest echoing her calm, confident grace.

name: Freyalise, Llanowar's Fury
rules:
+2: Search your library for an enchantment or an artifact card and put it into your hand.
-2: Destroy target artifact or enchantment. {BL} {BL} If the target is a permanent you control, Freyalise gains three loyalty counters.
-7: Draw a card for each green creature you control and target opponents discards a card for each nongreen creature in play.
flavor: “Winter taught me patience. Llanowar taught me what to do when patience runs out.”
lore: In the Ice Age’s harshest years, Freyalise forged an alliance with the Llanowar tribes, answering their threats with a fierce, protective magic that few had ever seen. She hunted down relics that drained the land’s life, destroying them with a fire that seemed almost born of the forest itself. Her rising power inspired the clans to fight as one, knowing her fury stood ready behind every blade of green.
art: Wind stirs her cloak and hair as the forest leans toward her, as though recognizing one of its own. Her allure is matched only by the certainty in her posture—the quiet authority of someone born to command the wild. Her expression blends grace with rising power, the kind of poised fury that makes even winter hesitate.

name: Fyndhorn Forest
rules:
Fyndhorn Forest enters play tapped unless you have a green creature and a green instant card in your graveyard.
{Tn}: Add {Gs}{Gs}.
Green spells you cast cost {Gs} less to cast.
Nonsnow Forests you control produce snow mana.
flavor: The cold could claim the plains and the mountains, but Fyndhorn kept a heartbeat the frost could never quiet.
lore: In the shadow of Argoth’s memory, Fyndhorn became a sanctuary of life during a world locked in ice. Its druids discovered that certain rites, performed with living companions and primal spells, awakened deeper currents beneath the conifers. That bond allowed the forest to nurture more than trees—it nurtured the strength of all who walked in the forest.
art: Snow settles softly on towering pines as a faint winter sun drifts over the valley. The forest feels ancient and aware, its quiet beauty carrying the promise of shelter and strength.

name: Gendrin, Rimewind Keeper
rules:
{Flash}`Flash`  {HexproofS}`Hexproof from snow`
Snow creatures you control get +1/+1.
Whenever you cast a blue or a snow spell, draw a card, then discard a card.
{Tn}: Target player mills 2 cards, then draws a card for each snow card milled this way.
Sacrifice Gendrin if Heidar’s in play.
flavor: “Mastery of frost is simple: outlast the weak, outthink the strong.”
lore: Gendrin ruled Rimewind Keep with a scholar’s patience and a tyrant’s precision, weaving frost magic into both his followers and his research. He taught that true knowledge came from surrendering one’s thoughts to the cold, letting the ice sift through them for what mattered. The keep’s secrets deepened under his guidance, even as Heidar watched, waiting for the moment when a magician’s brilliance would become a fatal vulnerability.
art: A brittle wind curls around Gendrin’s staff as he stands before the glacier’s fractured mouth, its blue glow gathering at his gesture. The frozen cliffs feel like an extension of his will—unyielding, exacting, ancient.

name: Gerda Aagesdotter
rules:
Wizards your opponents control get -0/-2.
Whenever an opponent casts a spell, the next instant, sorcery, or enchantment spell you cast this turn costs {1s}{Us} less to cast.
{Bs}{Bs}, {Tn}: Target nonblack creature becomes black instead of any other color.
{Us}{Us}, {Tn}: Gain control of target black creature. It gets a +1/+1 counter.
flavor: “Some say ambition corrupts; I find it clarifies.”
lore: Long before the Thaw, Gerda Aagesdotter served as Jodah’s formidable deputy at the School of the Unseen, her talent sharpened by envy and an instinct for political leverage. Her brief alliance with Gustha Ebbasdotter and Lim-Dûl left a lingering stain upon her, a secret she hid behind immaculate robes and an intimidating poise. Rumors whispered that her presence alone weakened rival mages, and that those who cast spells near her found their own magic bending unexpectedly in her favor.
art: A veil of snow eddies through the broken hall, catching on her robes like shards of blue glass. Her lifted chin and steady gaze suggest a mage accustomed to command—and unaccustomed to apology.

name: Glacial Revelation
rules:
Until end of turn, each card in your hand gains ‘Cycling {1s}. Color of mana paid must match the card’s color.’
Creatures your opponents control get –X/-0 until end of turn, where X is the number of cards you cycled this turn.
At the next end step, draw a card for each card you cycled this turn.
flavor: Shifting ice unveils more than stone; it unveils the secrets that feared the sun.
lore: Melting fault-lines near Balduvia exposed ancient tunnels abandoned during Lim-Dûl’s rise. Their walls shimmered with arcane residue that stirred when touched by living will. Witnesses described sudden flashes of clarity followed by a ripple of weakness in their foes, as though the revelations siphoned focus from everyone nearby. These caverns soon became pilgrimage sites for those desperate to reclaim lost knowledge from the Age of Ice.
art: Shattered frost hangs in sheets while a column of pale light cuts through the cavern roof. Reflections ripple across the icy walls, forming shapes that resemble forgotten diagrams. The traveler moves forward carefully, as though each step might wake the cave’s memory.

name: Glimmer Vale
rules:
Glimmer Vale enters play tapped.
{Tn}: Add one mana of any color. You may put a treasure token on Glimmer Vale.
{Tn}: Remove X treasure tokens from Glimmer Vale. Add X mana of any color.
{3s}, {Tn}, Sacrifice this land: Copy target spell. You may choose new targets for it.
flavor: Beneath Raynor’s shadow, even the ice pretends to be treasure.
lore: Glimmer Vale lay beneath the Raynor Glacier, its floor coated in churned mica that glittered like gold and lured countless wanderers into disappointment. Jaya Ballard fled here after taking back Jodah’s Mirror, trusting the vale’s deceptive brightness to mask her trail. Belenda Danisdotter carried her across the frozen basin to the hidden refuge where Jodah waited, surrounded by cliffs that shimmered like false treasure.
art: The vale stretches out beneath towering cliffs, each ridge dusted with mica that scatters pale gold across the ice. A frozen basin lies below like a polished mirror, faint blue light pulsing from its depths as the glacier looms overhead.

name: Great Glacier
rules:
{Tn}: Add {Cs} or {Us}.
{Ss}, {Tn}: Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt this turn.
{Us}{Us}: Great Glacier becomes a 0/8 Wall creature with defender until end of turn. It’s still a land.
flavor: Jodah’s magic made the glacier impassable.
lore: The Great Glacier sprawled across western Terisiare, burying valleys, forests, and entire mountain ranges beneath centuries of frozen weight. Jodah harnessed its immensity to conjure a Glacial Wall along its edge, sealing the School of the Unseen behind an impenetrable barrier. For decades no army, mage, or wanderer crossed its face, and Lat-Nam remained safe until the Thaw broke the glacier’s hold and the sea reclaimed the land.
art: A colossal ridge of ice rises like a continent unto itself, sheer and blinding beneath the pale light. Its frozen face stretches endlessly across the landscape, casting a cold shadow over the barren ground. The wind sculpts faint ridges where the glacier’s weight presses forward.

name: Grenfell Mor of Golthonor
rules:
+1: Draw a card, then discard a card. If a noncreature, nonland card was discarded this way, each opponent mills two cards.
-2: Choose one — Exile target artifact or enchantment; or distribute three -1/-1 counters among one or two target creatures.
-8: Create a 10/11 blue legendary Leviathan creature token with trample, hexproof, and menace named Valthus the Leviathan.
flavor: “Power is a blade. Wisdom is knowing where not to cut.”
lore: Grenfell Mor walked Dominaria’s courts and deserts as both scholar and survivor, shaping its history from the shadows while refusing to bend to Ravidel’s threats. His rust spell and the hidden long-daggers marked him as a guardian of dangerous knowledge, even as exile hardened him into a colder, more ruthless mage. Valthus the Leviathan followed as his final creation—a tideborn beast meant to judge those who failed the legacy he believed he alone could steward.
art: He holds the golden dagger aloft, its edge catching pale light against a backdrop of rolling sky. His stance is resolute, the scars on his arms hinting at battles fought across deserts and seas. The wind threads through his hair like an old companion.

name: Groth Jonar
rules:
{FirstStrike}`First strike`  {Menace}`Menace`
Other Orc creatures you control get +2/+2.
When Groth Jonar enters play or attacks, you may sacrifice a creature. If you do, draw a card and Groth deals 4 damage to any target.
At your end step, if an opponent controls more creatures than you, Groth Jonar deals 3 damage to that player.
flavor: “Victory is simple—hit first, hit hardest, hit last.”
lore: Groth Jonar’s path from clansman to general was carved through the harsh pragmatism of Balduvia’s endless conflict. At Balesh Pass, Elkan’s attempt to engineer an orcish massacre pushed Jonar to seize control of the battle, sacrificing the Flarg goblins and overwhelming the Kjeldorans with calculated fury. Elkan’s death at Jonar’s hand became legend, as did the general’s choice to spare the routed knights and claim only their banner as his prize.
art: Jonar stands amid wind-whipped snow with mountains rising behind him, muscles taut beneath battered armor. His spear gleams coldly as frost clings to the iron plates on his shoulders, capturing the raw force that made him a terror of Balduvia’s warfronts.

name: Guldark, Torgash Leader
rules:
{Menace}`Menace`  {Fear}`Fear`  {Haste}`Haste`
Sacrifice Guldark if Vannemir is in play.
Whenever a creature you don’t own dies, Guldark deals 2 damage to its owner.
{Tn}: Gain control of target creature an opponent controls until Guldark leaves play. That creature doesn’t untap during its controller’s untap step.
flavor: “Screams are a lot more truthful than words.”
lore: Feared along Balduvia’s frontiers, Guldark drove the Torgash and the Graks in raids that fed Rimewind’s rising storm, taking prisoners for sport and slaughtering settlements without remorse. The abduction of Pik’s sister and the unnamed elven girl drew Vannemir to his camp, where the warlord met a spirit-forged foe beyond anything he had prepared for. Their final clash became legend—the moment Guldark’s rage met Vannemir’s destiny and was carved apart before his entire clan.
art: Guldark strides through swirling snow with a predator’s confidence, muscles bound in leather, iron, and ritual scars. His breath curls like smoke as his weapon hangs ready, the storm-lit skies behind him echoing his raw, unbridled ferocity.

name: Gustha Ebbasdotter
rules:
{Ward}`Ward`—Discard a creature card.
Whenever you cast an instant or a sorcery spell, you may copy it. If you do, choose new targets for the copy.
{1s}: Tap or untap target permanent that shares a color with mana paid to activate this ability. #(Colorless counts as color.)#
When Gustha dies, draw 3 cards.
flavor: “If beauty and brilliance offends you, avert your eyes.”
lore: Gustha Ebbasdotter served as Kjeldor’s royal mage and led the Academy of Magic with a sharp mind and sharper discipline, earning her the nickname “Gusty the Royal Pain.” Though she aided her cousin Gerda in the conspiracy that delivered Jodah into Lim-Dûl’s hands, remorse drove her to break from the scheme and ultimately stand with Kjeldor against the necromancer. She died in the Battle of Fyndhorn forest, overwhelmed by undead after expending every spell she had left while shielding her allies.
art: A soft, cold radiance illuminates Gustha’s features as conjured vapors coil into shape beside her. Her posture is serene yet commanding, the drape of her robe hinting at both beauty and discipline. The ruined chamber around her feels held together by her presence alone.

name: Halvor Arenson
rules:
{Lifelink}`Lifelink`  {HexproofB}`Hexproof from black`
Whenever damage would be dealt to another creature you control, you may pay {Ws} to prevent it. If you do, put a +1/+1 counter on Halvor and on that creature.
{Ws}, {Tn}: Exile target black creature.
When Halvor dies, if you control a Druid or Elf, draw 2 cards and gain 6 life.
flavor: “Faith is no shield. Faith is the will to stand without one.”
lore: A humble cleric hardened by countless winters, Halvor tended the village of Mikkel and raised young Kaysa in the traditions of Kjeld. His distrust of Kolbjorn’s elven ties clashed with the druid’s claim that Kaysa bore the Elder Druid’s mark, tension that broke when undead villagers stormed the church under Lim-Dûl’s influence. Halvor’s defiant sunlight held the line until Freyalise’s power swept the dead away, leaving him grief-stricken yet willing to let Kaysa join Kolbjorn in the forests of Fyndhorn.
art: Snow drifts around Halvor as he gestures with a sphere of warm, healing light, its glow reflecting off aged stone and icy ground. His stance is calm but resolute, the bearing of a man who has stood between innocence and death too many times.

name: Hilde the Collector
rules:
{Ward}`Ward`—Exile the top card of your library.
Whenever Hilde the Collector enters play or attacks, you may search target opponent’s library for a card and exile it. If you do, you may pay 1 life to put the exiled card in your hand instead; or to draw a card.
{4s}, {Tn}, Sacrifice Hilde the Collector: Exile up to three cards from target opponent’s library face down. You may play those cards.
flavor: “Curses don’t frighten me. Boredom does.”
lore: Hilde wandered the snowbound markets of Kjeldor hunting relics others feared to touch, drawn to objects whispered to warp luck, memory, or sanity. Tales followed her like smoke—traders claiming she handled cursed treasures without flinching, scholars swearing she laughed at omens that made veterans shiver. She was last seen examining a skull-shaped charm said to doom its holder, laughing as if it had told her a private joke.
art: A winter wind tugs at Hilde’s green cloak as she raises a skull-shaped mask, its hollow eyes catching the moonlight. Her smile is bright and knowing, radiating the confidence of someone who dances comfortably with danger.

name: Holy Book of the Confessors
rules:
Creatures you control get +0/+1 and gain vigilance and ward {2s}.
{2s}, {Tn}: Scry 1, then draw a card.
Whenever you cast an enchantment, draw a card and gain 2 life.
Whenever you cast the second spell this turn, scry 2, then draw a card.
flavor: The song mages claim the Book answers truthfully—just never in the language you expect.
lore: The Confessors of Sumifa guarded the Book through centuries of frost and war, trusting its daily visions even when they defied reason. The messages came as riddles — commands, comforts, or distant warnings — carried in a voice none could name. Song mages learned to weave its utterances into their sacred chants, believing the Book spoke from a place older than the Ice Age itself.
art: The Book rests in a circle of frost-bleached candle stubs, its parchment alive with a slow, spiraling luminescence. Shadows bend toward it, drawn as if listening. Every line, every stroke of ink, feels shaped by centuries of whispered guidance meant for those bold enough to seek its counsel.

name: Hypocrisy of the Tal
rules:
White spells cost {1s}{Bs} less to cast.
Whenever you cast a nonwhite spell, put a diminishing counter on this card.
Whenever you cast a white spell or when Hypocrisy of the Tal leaves play, gain X life and each opponent loses X life where X is twice the number of diminishing counters on this enchantment.
flavor: Their sunburst banners shone with virtue; their footsteps carried shadows just as long.
lore: During the Ice Age’s long dawn, the Church of Tal still stoked fear of sorcery, insisting purity could only be achieved through obedience. But scholars found that many “holy recitations” mirrored ancient Yotian sun-magic, casting light that healed, shielded, and guided. The hypocrisy could no longer be buried, and the Talites’ influence diminished with every whispered truth.
art: The congregation crowds the frozen courtyard, their shadows long against the pale walls of the cathedral. Golden illumination blooms behind stained glass, catching edges of their cloaks as they pass. The scene feels reverent and uneasy at once — devotion drawn toward a source of power they claim to renounce.

name: Ib Halfheart, Goblin Tactician
rules:
{Menace}`Menace`  {Mountainwalk}`Mountainwalk`
Whenever you win a coin flip, draw a card.
Whenever a red creature you control becomes blocked, you may sacrifice it. If you do, it deals 4 damage to each blocking creature.
{Tn}: Attacking creatures you control get +3/+0 until end of turn. At end of combat, flip a coin for each—if you lose, sacrifice it.
flavor: “Retreat is just an advance in the other direction. And I’m very advanced.”
lore: During the Ice Age, Ib led a clutch of goblins who mistook frantic improvisation for strategy. His “tactics” usually involved throwing himself into battle last and taking credit first, a pattern as familiar to the tribes as the snow underfoot. Yet even in cowardice, Ib stirred a reckless courage in others, turning panic into something almost heroic.
art: Ib bounds across a wind-scoured ridge, snow whipping around his boots as distant peaks fade into the cold glare. His grin cuts through the frost, eyes bright with that blend of terror and enthusiasm only goblins master. The landscape feels like it’s one misstep from disaster — exactly the sort of place he thrives.

name: Il-Chunt, the Mask Model
rules:
{Menace}`Menace`  {Fear}`Fear`  {Haste}`Haste`
If there are no Humans or Barbarians in play, Il-Chunt, the Mask Model loses haste.
{Rs}: Il-Chunt, the Mask Model gains a single target creature’s ability until end of turn.
Whenever Il-Chunt becomes blocked, defending player discards a card at random.
flavor: “Who stole my mask? Filthy ugly thief!”
lore: Travelers whispered of Lagfrak the Low, a human brigand who hid behind a twisted goblin mask to sow fear across winter villages. The ruse unraveled when the mask’s “model” discovered the theft. Il-Chunt pursued Lagfrak with startling speed, reclaiming both his face and the notoriety attached to it. From then on, the legend walked on its own two mismatched feet.
art: Il-Chunt charges through drifting snow, his silhouette cutting stark lines against distant cliffs. Torn cloth flutters around him, hinting at countless scrapes and escapes. The world feels hostile and empty, yet he moves with the manic confidence of something born from its shadows rather than threatened by them.

name: Isa, Fylgja Panthera
rules:
{FirstStrike}`First strike`  {Shadow3}`Shadow`  {Snowwalk}`Snowwalk`
As long as you control a legendary Human creature, Isa, Fylgja Panthera gets +2/+2 and has indestructible and lifelink.
{Ws}{Bs}: Choose one—Target creature gains first strike, deathtouch, lifelink, or shadow until end of turn; or prevent all damage dealt to target creature this turn.
flavor: Some guardians bear shields. Vannemir’s walked beside him on silent paws of starlight.
lore: Born as a snow-leopard spirit of the high ridges, Isa was bound into a runeblade long before the Thaw. When Ysidra raised Vannemir from death, she joined their fates, letting Isa pour from steel into mortal flesh. The fylgja’s presence turned a weary warrior into a prowling storm, and her bond with human heroes has echoed through Kjeldoran sagas ever since.
art: Isa strides through a narrow snow-choked pass, jaws parted in a soundless roar as her coat blurs at the edges into spirit-light. The drifts give way beneath her without leaving tracks, as if the land itself remembers each step.

name: Island of Lat-Nam
rules:
Island of Lat-Nam enters play tapped unless you have a blue creature and a blue instant card in your graveyard.
{Tn}: Add {Us}{Us}.
Blue spells you cast cost {Us} less to cast.
Nonsnow Islands you control produce snow mana.
flavor: Behind the glacier’s wall, Lat-Nam slept in poisoned silence, yet its waters still whispered lessons to those who listened.
lore: As the Great Glacier crawled south, Lat-Nam became half-buried and half-revealed, its coastline a maze of ice shelves and hidden inlets. The School of the Unseen cloaked the island in wards that twisted sight and memory, ensuring only the most disciplined minds could navigate its approach. Those who did were rewarded with currents of mana so pure that ordinary spellcraft felt clumsy by comparison.
art: A lone island lies under a white sky, its mountains sharp and cold as unsheathed blades. The ice floes around it form spiraling channels, almost too precise to be natural, guiding the eye toward a hidden bay at the island’s heart. Subtle radiance clings to the water’s surface, suggesting that every wave and crevasse remembers the lessons of the Unseen.

name: Jaeuhl Carthalion
rules:
{FirstStrike}`First strike`  {Vigilance}`Vigilance`
You may draw cards from an opponent’s library.
Jaeuhl Carthalion can block creatures with fear, shadow, horsemanship, menace, and landwalk abilities as though they didn’t have those abilities.
As long as you control a Druid or an Elf, Jaeuhl Carthalion gets +3/+2 and gains indestructible.
Whenever Jaeuhl attacks, you may pay {Ws}. If you do, exile target nonland permanent.
flavor: “Courage isn’t a banner. It’s the quiet promise you make when no one’s left to hear it.”
lore: Jaeuhl’s rise came at a time when the world choked beneath ice and despair. With Freyalise’s guidance, he mastered the Celestial Sword, endured Szat’s necromancy, and fought beside Balduvians, Yavimayans, and skyknights alike. His journey forged new bonds between human and elf kind — ties that later guided him deep into Yavimaya to defend its ancient heart.
art: Cold mist coils between the trees as Jaeuhl advances, eyes fixed ahead, the Celestial Sword humming with restrained power. Snowflakes cling to his cloak, caught in the brilliance radiating from his weapon. The wilderness frames him not as a wanderer but as someone chosen — and burdened — by forces deeper than the season.

name: Jasha Carthalion
rules:
#Landfall# — Whenever a land enters play, you may untap up to two target lands.
As long as Jasha is untapped, green and white creatures you control get +2/+2.
During your upkeep, if you control five or more lands, remove all counters in play.
Whenever you cast a green or a white spell, you may gain 2 life.
flavor: “Strength is inherited; wisdom is earned; harmony is chosen.”
lore: Jasha’s youth unfolded in the first decades of the Thaw, when forests returned in hesitant patches and old druidic rites awakened beneath the soil. Guided by Kaysa’s teachings and Jaeuhl’s unyielding sense of duty, she united the surviving circles of Terisiare. Under her hand, the land itself grew bold again, answering her call with new rivers, new boughs, and new hope.
art: Jasha stands among thawing evergreens, Kaysa’s druid-staff glowing with the soft green fire once carried by the Fyndhorn circles. The air around her stirs faintly, as if the awakening forest is breathing with her. Snow recedes beneath her presence, suggesting a land eager to answer its new guardian.

name: Jason Carthalion
rules:
{FirstStrike}`First strike`  {Reach}`Reach`  {Forestwalk}`Forestwalk`
As long as Jason Carthalion is enchanted, he gets +1/+2 and has indestructible.
{Gs}, {Tn}: Jason deals damage equal to his power to target creature with flying.
Whenever Jason Carthalion deals combat damage to a player, put a +1/+1 counter on each other Human you control.
flavor: “Strength grows in the quiet moments between arrows.”
lore: Jason Carthalion rose from Storgard’s dwindling clans as an untested wielder of green mana, shaped under the guidance of Oriel Kjeldos. When King Miko forced him to duel his childhood friend Freyalise, Jason bore the Fyndhorn Bow and the Shield of the Ages, tools that carried him to victory — and carried Freyalise into unforeseen ascension.
art: Jason strides through the winter woods with the Fyndhorn Bow held low and the Shield of the Ages strapped firm across his arm. Snow clings to his boots and bracers, but his expression is steady, as if the cold is an old companion.

name: Jaya Ballard
rules:
+1: Add {Rs}{Rs}{Rs}. Spend this mana only to cast instant or sorcery spells.
-1: Discard up to three cards, then draw that many cards. Jaya deals 1 damage to any target for each instant or sorcery discarded or drawn this way.
-X: You may cast up to X instant or sorcery spells from your graveyard until end of turn. Creatures you control get +X/+0 until end of turn.
flavor: “You’d be amazed how many problems fit inside one well-placed inferno.”
lore: When her spark ignited in a tower of flame, Jaya Ballard did not linger in awe. She planeswalked straight back to the School of the Unseen, incinerated the war beasts rampaging through Lat-Nam, and helped Jodah seal Lim-Dûl’s bottomless pit beneath new wards of fire and ice. Only when the school stood safe did she finally turn outward, trading one embattled world for an infinity of new horizons.
art: Embers drift from Jaya’s torch, tiny comets spiraling into the grey sky as snowflakes melt before they land. The calm curve of her smile and the easy way she grips the staff say she’s long past proving herself to this world’s winter. She looks like someone pausing between journeys, already half-turned toward the next plane.

name: Jaya Ballard, Task Mage
rules:
{Rs}, {Tn}, Discard a card: Destroy target wall, snow land, or blue permanent.
{1s}{Rs}, {Tn}, Discard a card: Jaya Ballard, Task Mage deals 4 damage to any target. If target is a creature with indestructible, it loses that ability until end of turn.
{5s}{Rs}{Rs}, {Tn}, Discard a card: Jaya Ballard deals 7 damage to all targets.
flavor: “If it burns, it’s a solution. If it doesn’t burn, give me a second.”
lore: Before becoming a planeswalker, Jaya Ballard made her reputation the old-fashioned way: by setting things on fire for coin. Wandering from Kjeld to Kelsinko, she sold her magic to villages choking under storms, raiders, or inconveniently solid walls of ice. Her temper was quick, her spells quicker, and her talent so obvious that even Jodah briefly hoped she might stay in Lat-Nam long enough to finish a lesson.
art: Jaya strides through the swirling frost as her hands bloom into bright, hungry flames that scatter sparks into the wind. Her grin carries the reckless confidence of someone who treats winter as a personal insult. She looks in command of the moment, the place, and the temperature.

name: Jaya the Possessed
rules:
{Bs}{Rs}, {Tn}, Pay 2 life: Destroy target land.
{1s}{Bs}{Rs}, {Tn}, Pay 3 life: Jaya deals 4 damage divided among any number of targets.
{Bs}{Bs}{Bs}{Rs}{Rs}{Rs}, {Tn}, Pay 4 life: Return up to five creatures from graveyards to play under your control.
If Jaya would leave play, exile another creature you control instead.
flavor: “I hear a voice in my head. The problem is—it’s right.”
lore: The ruby ring she slipped onto her finger carried the ghost of Mairsil, and little by little his whispers replaced her instincts. She wandered the Ice Age like a weapon with no master, burning what offended her, breaking what resisted, and smiling through the pain of a will not entirely her own. The mages of Soldev saw only Jaya’s flames—not the invisible hand twisting them. Only Jodah noticed the hollowness behind her humor.
art: In the deepening dusk, Jaya’s magic twists into a perfect circle, a shape too deliberate for her usual improvisation. Her stance is confident, yet her gaze carries a distant, haunted tension, as if two minds are looking out through the same eyes.

name: Jodah, Alliance Architect
rules:
When Jodah enters play, search all libraries for a planeswalker and put it into your hand.
Whenever a permanent you control becomes the target of a spell or ability an opponent controls, put a +1/+1 counter on Jodah.
{Cs}{Ws}{Us}{Bs}{Rs}{Gs}, {Tn}, Sacrifice Jodah: Destroy all lands. Search all libraries for an artifact creature card and put it into play under your control. Draw two cards.
flavor: “If history insists on repeating itself, I may as well rewrite the chorus.”
lore: In the uneasy quiet after Lim-Dûl’s fall, Jodah became the quiet mathematician behind a continent-wide truce. While kings and jarls argued over scars, he steered both sides toward the future that neither could build alone. The Balduvian–Kjeldoran pact that followed bore his invisible signature: a design of patience, leverage, and the gentle nudging of a man who had watched empires rise and misbehave for two millennia. His guidance shaped the first stones of New Argive and gave the North its first shared future since the Brothers left the world broken.
art: Jodah stands at the center of the gathering storm, a sphere of blue-white mana glowing between his hands. The light reflects off the snow like a beacon, casting the cloaked figures behind him in shifting shadows. His expression is calm and resolute — the look of a man orchestrating the shape of an entire continent.

name: Jodah, Archmage Eternal
rules:
{Flying}`Flying`
You may pay {Ws}{Us}{Bs}{Rs}{Gs} to cast spells instead of their mana cost.
Whenever Jodah, Archmage Eternal dies, exile him instead. If you do, return Jodah to your hand during your next upkeep.
flavor: “Don’t think immortality is a gift. It’s an obligation.”
lore: After the fall of the City of Shadows and the birth of the School of the Unseen, Jodah’s reputation stretched farther than the safe havens that sheltered the North. His command of every color of mana turned into whispered proof that he had outgrown mortality itself. He acted rarely, intervened sparingly, and watched tirelessly — a guardian who knew that the world changed more predictably when he did not.
art: Jodah hovers above an explosion of crystalline energy, the flare painting the storm in shards of color. His expression is calm, almost detached — the look of someone who has shaped magic for so long that gravity itself becomes a matter of preference.

name: Jodah, the Researcher
rules:
Jodah enters play with 5 research counters on him. During your upkeep, remove a research counter from Jodah. If you do, scry 2.
{Tn}: Destroy target planeswalker or legendary creature. Activate only if there are no research counters on Jodah, the Researcher.
When there are no research counters, planeswalkers, or legendary creatures in play apart from Jodah, you win the game.
flavor: “Some truths change the world. Others change the one who discovers them.”
lore: Deep under Tresserhorn, Jodah labored under enchantments meant to turn him into the perfect researcher—obedient, brilliant, and forgetful. The pollen blurred his past, but flashes of truth still cut through the haze: his stolen mirror, the betrayal of Gerda and Gustha, the necromancer’s rising ambitions. With each forced discovery, he quietly planned the moment he would remember himself fully.
art: Jodah studies by dim candlelight in a narrow stone chamber, parchments stacked like a jailer’s walls. His eyes carry the distant shine of someone fighting through pollen-fogged memories, yet his hands move with steady, practiced magic. A shadow beyond the arch hints at Tresserhorn’s unseen watchers.

name: Jodah's Mirror
rules:
You have hexproof.
{3s}, {Tn}: Exile a card from play, your hand, or your graveyard face down. It gains flash. Then, if there are three or more cards exiled with Jodah’s Mirror, you may cast one of those cards without paying its mana cost.
{4s}, {Tn}, Sacrifice Jodah’s Mirror: Set your life total equal to your starting life. Discard your hand, then draw five cards.
flavor:
“A mirror is only harmless until the day it remembers more than you do.”
—Jodah, Archmage Eternal
lore: The mirror Voska gave him became Jodah’s anchor in an age that tried to grind him down. It steadied Ith’s mind, preserved Jodah’s memories through the centuries, and later amplified the World Spell across Fyndhorn. Only after Freyalise wove a planeswalker-spark trap into its heart did he fear it—and that fear proved justified when he shattered it to free Jaya from Mairsil’s grasp.
art: Jodah stands against a frozen night, holding the Reflecting Mirror as moonlight scatters across its surface. The swirling frost within hints at the memories stored inside—decades folded upon centuries, condensed like breath on glass.

name: Jornstad
rules:
Jornstad enters play with 11 siege counters on it. Whenever a creature you control blocks or whenever you tap this land for mana, remove a siege counter from Jornstad.
{Tn}: Add {Ws}.
When there are no siege counters on Jornstad, sacrifice it, then create a legendary 11/11 green snow Wurm creature token with trample named Rhindle, the Scaled Wurm.
flavor: Merchants come for trade, pilgrims for solace, soldiers for warmth. Everyone lingers in Jornstad, including winter.
lore: Jornstad’s gardens, markets, and marble fountains made it the jewel of Eastern Kjeldor, a city where wizards and woodcutters shared the same bustling avenues. It was one of the rare places in the Ice Age where culture endured as fiercely as the cold.
art: Evening light glows against timbered walls while travelers weave through Jornstad’s winter thoroughfare. Smoke from tavern chimneys drifts into the cold air, softening the stone towers and distant peaks.

name: Karplusan Mountains
rules:
Karplusan Mountains enters play tapped unless you have a red creature and a red instant card in your graveyard.
{Tn}: Add {Rs}{Rs}.
Red spells you cast cost {Rs} less to cast.
Nonsnow Mountains you control produce snow mana.
flavor: Between Kjeldor and Balduvia stood no wall—only mountains everyone considered as one.
lore: Once known as the Sardian Mountains, the range became the Karplusans as ice overtook the dwarves’ old holds and reshaped the land. Throughout the Ice Age, the peaks served as both barrier and battlefield, marking the uneasy frontier between Kjeldor’s disciplined soldiers and Balduvia’s fierce clans.
art: The landscape unfurls in alternating bands of snow, rock, and shadow. A river gleams faintly in the distance, threading through the mountains like a sliver of thaw beneath towering, indifferent heights.

name: Kelsinko
rules:
{Tn}: Add {Gs}.
{Gs}{Gs}{Gs}, {Tn}: Target opponent searches your library for a green permanent and puts it into play under your control.
{Tn}, #Blizzard# — Exile Kelsinko until end of turn: Forests you control become snow and deal 1 damage to any target when tapped for mana during a #Blizzard#.
flavor: Where the forest breathed deepest, Kelsinko learned to breathe with it.
lore: Built on Citanul’s bones, Kelsinko stood as a rare harmony between the forest’s elves and the nearby human clans. It witnessed Freyalise’s World Spell and celebrated the promise of renewal. Yet the promise turned to flooding, and its survivors fled toward Yavimaya while the sea swallowed their plazas and murals.
art: Nestled on terraces above a pale river, Kelsinko’s timbered homes and tall green towers shine with warm, scattered light. The forest presses close around the settlement while beyond them, the mountains stretch in layered blues and greys, a quiet reminder of how small even the proudest towns can feel in the Ice Age.

name: Kher Ridges
flavor: Climb high enough and the past looks close enough to touch.
lore: Even in the Ice Age, the Ridges felt older than the cold itself. Travelers spoke of hidden halls carved before written memory, and of a presence deep within the stone that stirred whenever metal rang against rock. Scholars of the Brothers’ War insisted the truth was stranger—half-buried forges, collapsed vaults, and relics humming with old power that refused to die quietly.
art: Snow clings to fractured stone as the trail dips into a sweeping basin carved by centuries of shifting ice. The ridges loom in uneven silhouettes—silent, weathered witnesses to the secrets buried far beneath their broken spines.

name: Kjeld
rules:
{Tn}: Add {Ws}.
{Ws}{Ws}{Ws}, {Tn}: Target opponent searches your library for a white permanent and puts it into play under your control.
{Tn}, #Blizzard# — Exile Kjeld until end of turn: Plains you control become snow and deal 1 damage to any target when tapped for mana during a #Blizzard#.
flavor:
“A city can freeze, but devotion—that burns long after the torches die.”
—Zaraya, Kjeldoran Commander
lore: Raised upon the bones of fallen Penregon, Kjeld remained a symbol of order in a world sliding into ice. Beneath its spires, kings plotted diplomacy with Balduvia while the Knights of Kjeldor prepared for wars that threatened to swallow every warm light in the realm.
art: Kjeld’s skyline rises from the ice like a monument carved by some patient titan—spires, arches, and battlements bathed in a fading sun. The stillness of the sea mirrors the quiet determination of the people sheltered within its walls.

name: Kjeldoran Hinterlands
rules:
This land enters play tapped unless you have a white creature and a white instant card in your graveyard.
{Tn}: Add {Ws}{Ws}.
White spells you cast cost {Ws} less to cast.
Nonsnow Plains you control produce snow mana.
flavor:
“Wind is the only sovereign out here. We’re just guests who hope it stays in a good mood.”
—Zaraya, Kjeldoran Commander
lore: Beyond Kjeld’s marble towers stretched the raw wild of eastern Terisiare. Farmers, riders, and patrols held these open plains against storms, beasts, and frost giants alike, forming the thin human thread that linked the capital to the farthest reaches of Kjeldor.
art: Muted winter light drapes the prairie where cold winds flatten brittle grass. The atmosphere captures the solitude of far-flung Kjeldoran plains, places where villages are few and every storm feels like a test delivered by the age itself.

name: Kjeldoran Marshes
flavor: Kjeldor’s borders never ended at its walls. Some borders were simply places no sane rider wished to cross.
lore: These sodden lowlands stretched between Kjeld’s outermost villages and the white deserts beyond, a bleak frontier the crown never fully tamed. In the last years of Lim-Dûl’s rise, more than one scouting party vanished into the fog here, leaving only their frost-bitten banners behind.
art: A drowned field lies silent under the Ice Age sky, the last stubborn tree half-buried in frozen mud. The horizon fades beneath sheets of mist, leaving the land suspended between stillness and storm.

name: Klazina Jansdotter
rules:
{DoubleStrike}`Double strike`  {Vigilance}`Vigilance`  {Lifelink}`Lifelink`      {Horsemanship}`Horsemanship`  {ProtectionR}`Protection from red`
Other white creatures you control get +1/+1.
Pay 1 life, {Tn}: Counter target black spell.
At your end step, if Klazina Jansdotter dealt damage this turn, draw a card.
{3s}{Ws}{Rs}, Sacrifice Klazina Jansdotter: Destroy all black and red creatures.
flavor: “Steel is honesty. Flame is conviction. I carry both.”
lore: Leader of the Order of the Sacred Torch, Klazina was fiercer than even her friend Lucilde Fiksdotter, quick-tempered and unwavering in purpose. She fought through the horrors at Mikkel, where undead villagers and the treacherous Avram Garrison tested her resolve. From that night onward, her fire burned hotter, driving her through Lim-Dûl’s final battle. When Jodah’s spell freed her from the ghoul that once led her order, Klazina rallied Kjeldor’s ranks and hurled the necromancer’s legions back into their own pyres.
art: Her flame glows against the cold as she advances across open tundra, commanding presence carried in every line of her poise and form. Gold-inlaid armor highlights her figure, a blend of sensual grace and seasoned discipline. Her steed’s immaculate stride evokes the relentless momentum she brought to the Sacred Torch as they rode against Lim-Dûl’s undead swarms.

name: Kolbjorn, Fyndhorn Elder
rules:
{Tn}: Add {Gs} for each snow land you control.
Non-animal creatures you control get +1/+1.
{Gs}, {Tn}: You gain 3 life.
{1s}{Gs}, {Tn}: Tap or untap all Forests.
When Kolbjörn dies, search your library for a green creature card and put it into your hand.
During your upkeep, you may return target land card from your graveyard to your hand.
flavor: “Age isn’t weight — it’s the shape wisdom leaves on a life.”
lore: Kolbjörn was the oldest Elder Druid Fyndhorn had ever known, a quiet pillar of strength through the darkest years of Lim-Dûl’s rise. With Disa at his side and Kaysa under his protection, he guided the forest clans with patience and steady warmth. When the horrors of Mikkel unfolded, it was his arrival that revealed the villagers’ fate and his wisdom that steadied the survivors until Freyalise’s chant restored peace.
art: Kolbjörn stands beneath towering winter pines, his cloak stirring like a living extension of the forest itself. Age has carved dignity into his posture, and the strength in his stance reflects a lifetime of communion with the land.

name: Kristina of the Woods
rules:
+2: Until your next turn, whenever a creature attacks you or a planeswalker you control, {BL} that creature gets a -1/-1 counter.
-2: Choose one — Exile target enchantment or artifact; or tap 2 target permanents. They don’t untap during their controller’s next untap step.
-10: Each player chooses 3 nonland permanents they control. Exile the rest. Draw cards equal to the number of cards exiled this way.
flavor: “I’ve crossed more worlds than endured winters here. Still, this forest feels like home.”
lore: Kristina entered the Ice Age with centuries of burden already behind her—alliances broken, hearts wounded, battles won through diplomacy and fire. The frozen forests of Terisiare and Corondor offered the solitude she needed after the turmoil of the Null Moon and her parting from Taysir. In those quiet snows, she shaped her identity anew: not as peacekeeper, lover, or exile, but as a planeswalker whose will could not be claimed by any power but her own.
art: In the pale glow beneath frozen boughs, Kristina’s silhouette is striking — the confident line of her jaw, the cascade of red hair, the natural allure refined by centuries of wandering. Her fingers brush the cold air as though shaping unseen energies, and the trees seem to hold their breath. Even in stillness, she radiates the quiet power of one who has walked between worlds.

name: Krov
flavor: Krov shone brightest when the world was darkest.
lore: At its height, Krov rivaled any city on Terisiare, drawing scholars to its academies and warriors to its skyknight aeries. Yet prosperity curdled after the Thaw. Plague surged through the alleys, vampires hunted in the darkened corners, and the Cult of Rimewind used Krov’s libraries to unearth forbidden machines. When Heidar betrayed the city, even Garza Zol’s assassins could not halt the collapse. A rising sea claimed the ruins soon after.
art: Krov lies spread beneath a brooding sky, its clustered homes and tall keeps rendered in muted stone and amber light. The royal district crowns the horizon, austere and imposing. Despite the night’s serenity, the air carries an uneasy stillness, the kind a city feels when history is about to turn against it.

name: Labyrinth of Raynor
rules:
Labyrinth of Raynor enters play tapped.
Opponents’ creatures enter play tapped.
{Tn}, Pay 2 life: Add {Bs}{Bs}{Bs}{Us}.
{Xs}, {Tn}: Reveal the top card of target player’s library. If its mana value equals X, you may play that card without paying its mana cost. X can’t be 0.
flavor: Those who enter seeking power seldom notice the cold until it finishes closing around them.
lore: The Raynor Glacier consumed the last stones of Storgard’s castle, burying a kingdom beneath centuries of frost. Within its shifting caverns lay the Labyrinth of Raynor—a maze where Tevesh Szat’s Phyrexian priest gathered dark mana in secret. At the Ice Age’s end, Jaeuhl Carthalion braved those frozen halls, retrieving the Amulet of Quoz from a chamber steeped in malevolent stillness.
art: The cavern’s mouth twists inward, carved by ancient pressures into a smooth, spiraling descent. Pale blue light glints off layered ice, drawing the eye toward a darkness that feels patient and aware. The floor is dusted with frost, unmarred as though few living things have risked stepping this far.

name: Lagfrak the Low
rules:
{Menace}`Menace`  {Haste}`Haste`
If there is a Goblin in play, Lagfrak the Low loses menace.
Lagfrak can only be blocked by creatures with power higher than Lagfrak.
Lagfrak can’t block creatures with toughness higher than Lagfrak.
flavor: “Turns out terror is easy. Keeping a goblin from reclaiming his mask? Impossible.”
lore: Lagfrak’s pranks escalated into full countryside terror when he donned a stolen mask crafted in honor of the goblin trickster Il-Chunt. Farmers whispered of a beast roaming the plains, half-man, half-nightmare. The truth emerged only when Il-Chunt himself confronted Lagfrak, outraged to discover his own features were being used to frighten children rather than entertain them.
art: Lagfrak sprints across open tundra, the stolen goblin mask clutched over his face as a crimson cloak lashes behind him. Muscles tense beneath rough-cut leathers, he radiates manic energy—equal parts bravado and desperation. The windswept plains blur around him, suggesting a chase he may not win.

name: Laina of the Elvish Council
rules:
{Vigilance}`Vigilance`  {Forestwalk}`Forestwalk`
Green spells you cast cost {1s}{Gs} less.
{Tn}: Add {Cs}{Cs}{Gs}. Spend this mana only to cast artifacts and/or activate their abilities.
If another creature you control would die, you may tap Laina. If you do, return that creature to play tapped.
flavor: “I guide the forest’s will—when it whispers, when it roars, and when it chooses to forgive.”
lore: Laina led the Fyndhorn elves during the harshest years of the Ice Age, her judgment steady even when Freyalise sought the Ice Cauldron for the World Spell. She doubted the danger Kaysa would face, resisting the goddess’s plans with quiet resolve. Later, in the expedition to Yavimaya, Laina stood alongside Jaeuhl Carthalion and Jaya Ballard, surviving the ambush of a Phyrexian War Beast and the forest’s wrath until elves and gorillas found common cause.
art: Her figure glows against a pale woodland backdrop, elegant and sure, with the composed strength of one accustomed to guiding clans through hardship. The folds of her blue-green robes accent her presence, lending her both grace and authority. Frost gathers on branches behind her, framing her in a quiet halo.

name: Leshrac, Walker of Night
rules:
+1: Choose one—Destroy target tapped land an opponent controls; or target creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn for each Swamp in play.
-3: Gain control of target untapped creature an opponent controls. It gains haste until end of turn. Exile it at the next end step.
-9: Exile all Planeswalkers and all legendary creatures from play, as well as from all graveyards, hands, and libraries.
flavor: “Pretend the dark is empty if you wish. I assure you it’s quite crowded.”
lore: During the Ice Age, Leshrac prowled the Shard of the Twelve Worlds, trapped yet relentless. He conspired with Tevesh Szat to claim Shandalar, using Lim-Dûl to raise an undead army meant to fuel their invasion. The plan collapsed when Jodah thwarted Lim-Dûl’s advance, leaving Leshrac to lash out at the Summit of the Null Moon before slipping away into the drifting pathways between the Shard and Shandalar.
art: Leshrac stands beneath a vast, moonlit sky, wings unfurled like living shadows. His alabaster skin and gaunt frame radiate a chilling, ageless power. The dark horizon seems to bend toward him, as though night itself answers his call.

name: Liana of Minorad
rules:
+2: Until your next turn, Liana of Minorad becomes a 4/4 Shapeshifter creature with indestructible, intimidate and changeling.
-X: Target player mills X cards. You may return an artifact or planeswalker with mana value X from a graveyard to play under your control.
-11: Each opponent exiles their entire hand and graveyard. You draw cards equal to the number of cards exiled this way.
flavor: “I shift to survive. It unsettles enemies—and infuriates tyrants.”
lore: Liana’s early life unfolded against the harsh winds and thinning mana of the Ice Age. Minorad was then a gathering point for mages displaced by the shard’s formation, and she quickly rose as one of their foremost Sages. Her shifting form allowed her to study magic from multiple perspectives, embodying roles needed in the moment—scout, scholar, protector. As the Ice Age waned and the World Spell neared completion, she helped anchor Minorad’s fragile stability amid the shifting tides of thawing power.
art: Her figure commands the snowy landscape, emerald cloak billowing as if shaped by unseen magic. Sharp features and confident posture reveal someone accustomed to changing shape and fate alike. The pale horizon behind her reinforces her connection to a world still locked in Ice Age tension.

name: Lim-Dul the Necromancer
flavor: “I do not raise the dead for power—I raise them because the living keep disappointing me.”
lore: Lim-Dûl rose from obscurity after claiming Mairsil’s ring within the frozen ruins of the Conclave of Mages. The artifact reshaped him into a necromancer of terrifying will, raising armies unnoticed while Kjeldor and Balduvia warred with each other. Under Leshrac’s manipulation, Lim-Dûl expanded his undead legions and twisted old heroes—such as Márton Stromgald. His ambition culminated in the great siege against united Kjeldoran and Balduvian forces.
art: A frigid wind whips Lim-Dûl’s tattered cloak as he strides across a mountain pass, the moon glowing through heavy cloud behind him. His gaze is sharp, ancient, and hungry, the kind that weighs life as though it were already dead. Every detail—leather straps, frost-bitten cloth, bony hand—speaks of a sorcerer who has embraced the cold as ally, not foe.

name: Lim-Dul the Soldier
flavor: “I wasn’t born for glory. I just wanted to survive the winter.”
lore: In youth, Lim-Dûl marched under Kjeldor’s banners, one face among many trudging through icebound campaigns. Officers dismissed him as quiet and unremarkable, unaware of the fierce intelligence behind his silence. When scouting missions grew increasingly reckless, he began to suspect Kjeldor valued his expendability more than his service—a truth that would leave deep cracks in his loyalty long before darkness ever found him.
art: Lim-Dûl pauses on a wind-scraped ridge, cloak and gear dusted with frost, eyes sharp beneath tousled hair. His posture carries the tension of someone who has seen danger but not yet found a way to master it.

name: Lord Balo Kailo
rules:
{FirstStrike}`First strike`  {Vigilance}`Vigilance`  {Reach}`Reach`
#Landfall# — Whenever a land enters play under your control, creatures you control get +1/+1 and gain vigilance until end of turn.
Whenever Lord Balo Kailo attacks, tap target creature an opponent controls. It doesn’t untap during its controller’s next untap step.
Whenever another legendary creature enters play, put a +1/+1 counter on Kailo.
flavor: “I lost my eye to the cold and my heart to the past. Only one of them grew back stronger.”
lore: Kailo’s eye was not the only thing he lost—his trust, his family, and much of his old self had been carved away by cold decisions and colder wars. Yet among the Knights of Kjeldor he remained an unfaltering presence: resolute, relentless, and impossible to mislead. Few trackers read the land as he did, and none carried the weight he bore with such quiet resolve.
art: Snow-dusted plate bends around his frame as Kailo studies a trail half-vanished in drifting frost, his stance steady and patient. The trees loom like solemn witnesses, giving his presence the air of a man shaped by loss but steeled by purpose.

name: Lord Rothchild
rules:
{Lifelink}`Lifelink`  {Ward}`Ward`—Discard two cards.
Lord Rothchild can’t be blocked except by Walls.
{Tn}: Target creature you control gets +4/+0 and gains first strike and vigilance until end of turn.
During your upkeep each opponent loses 1 life and you gain 1 life. If a creature died since your last upkeep, draw a card.
If Lord Rothchild would die, sacrifice another creature you control instead.
flavor: “The land is easy to rule when someone else does the ruling for you.”
lore: During the Ice Age, Lord Rothchild of Jornstad was the most beloved disappointment in all of Kjeldor. Wrapped in luxury and insulated from reality, he presided over his province while Duke Devareaux and the dutiful Finroy quietly carried the true weight of governance. He remained unaware that the people praised a man who seldom lifted a finger, and even less aware of how close Kjeldor drifted toward collapse.
art: Amid the muted blues of a winter interior, Rothchild lounges with a bottle loosely held, the trappings of wealth arranged around him like armor he never earned. His expression carries the serene confidence of someone who assumes the world will keep turning without his effort.

name: Lost Sword of the Ages
rules:
As an additional cost to equip Lost Sword of the Ages, sacrifice any number of creatures.
Equipped creature gains trample and gets +X/+1 where X equals the sum of sacrificed creatures’ power.
Equip {4s}
{4s}{Bs}{Rs}, Sacrifice Lost Sword of the Ages: It deals X damage to all targets where X equals the number of nonland permanents in play.
flavor: Most weapons sleep. This one dreams.
lore: The scholars of Soldev believed the four Artifacts of the Ages told the whole tale, until a buried monolith cracked to reveal a blade whose runes no scholar could place on any known timeline. Survivors of the dig spoke of pressure in the air, as though the sword drew strength from all things living and unliving around it. Some insisted it was not simply discovered, but reawakened.
art: The weapon rises from the tundra like a monument left by forgotten gods, its weathered steel resisting both rust and time. Fractured ice reflects the faint shimmer of ancient enchantments along the hilt. The sky bends low above it, uneasy in its presence.

name: Lothar Lovisason
rules:
Other Warriors, Barbarians, Soldiers, and Humans you control get +1/+0.
White creatures you control have haste.
Red creatures you control have vigilance.
Whenever red and white creatures attack together, put a +1/+1 counter on all of them.
{Rs}{Ws}, {Tn}: Destroy all snow permanents. Activate only if you control a Human female.
flavor: “My mother told me to lead with heart and fury. I added the smile.”
lore: Born in the first year of the Thaw, Lothar grew beneath the gaze of Lovisa Coldeyes—herself a force of nature, fierce, alluring, and legendary among Balduvian war-clans. Warriors swore that her very presence ignited battle-fervor, and Lothar inherited both her fire and her magnetism. As peace slowly took root across Terisiare, he forged ties between Balduvia and Kjeldor that even winter could not break.
art: Lothar stands against a wind-torn ridge, the red cloak inherited from his mother snapping behind him like living flame. The strength in his stance echoes the heroic poise Lovisa made famous among the Balduvians. Snow curls around him without daring to settle, as though recognizing a lineage carved from storms.

name: Lovisa the Harborer
rules:
{Vigilance}`Vigilance`  {Ward}`Ward`—Discard a card.
You may cast legendary creature cards as though they had flash. They have haste.
{1s}: Target creature gains protection from the same color as mana used to pay for this ability. #(Colorless counts as color.)#
{Tn}: Target legendary creature gains indestructible until end of turn.
flavor: “Balduvia has sharp winds and sharper women. I am both.”
lore: When Jaya Ballard and the broken Archmage Jodah fled the chaos of Lat-Nam, Lovisa took them into the wilds she ruled like a living avalanche. Her presence alone was enough to keep danger at bay—muscular, alluring, lethal, unmistakably Balduvian. In her shelter, Jodah slowly resurfaced from madness, steadied by the fierce warmth that only Lovisa could grant in a world of ice.
art: Lovisa strides forward, powerful and striking, the gleam of sunlit frost catching the sculpted contours of her body and the determined lift of her chin. Around her, the mountains feel smaller, as if recognizing the chieftain whose presence has outmatched storms, sieges, and secrets.

name: Lovisa, Martyr Queen
rules:
Creatures you control get +1/+1 for each Martyr card in play or in graveyards.
Whenever a Martyr card leaves play, untap all creatures you control and put a +1/+1 counter on each one. They all gain indestructible until end of turn.
When Lovisa, Martyr Queen dies, destroy all snow permanents.
flavor: “The cold can take my body, but it will never take the fire I inspired in my people.”
lore: Her last night beneath the blood-red moon became the most retold tale in Balduvia. Lovisa refused surrender, taunted Heidar’s mages, and fought until the ice was slick with thawed snow and her own blood. Yet those who survived remembered something stranger—a serenity, an almost luminous beauty, as if she knew her death would ignite a nation stronger than any army she commanded. In dying, she became the martyr queen her people still follow.
art: Lovisa’s figure rests beneath a burning red sky, her breath fading into the cold while the stones of Rimewind loom behind. Snow clings to her furs and bare skin, heightening the contrast between her lingering warmth and the harsh Ice Age around her. There is allure in her stillness, and a haunting sense that she chose the manner of her death.

name: Lucilde Fiksdotter
rules:
{Horsemanship}`Horsemanship`
Knights and Elves you control get +1/+1 and gain first strike and vigilance.
{Ws}{Gs}, {Tn}: Choose one—Exile target creature. Its controller gains life equal to its power; or target creature gains reach until end of turn.
Each turn, prevent 1 damage that would be dealt to each creature you control.
flavor: “Steel holds the line, but faith decides who walks away.”
lore: During the long march against Lim-Dûl, Lucilde became the spine of Kjeldor’s defenses. Stories say her shield never lowered and her temper never rose, even when her band of knights found themselves cornered in the snow-buried church of Mikkel. Surrounded by the dead, she fought with grim precision, holding back despair until Freyalise’s chant swept the corruption clean. In the hushed morning light she buried every villager herself, believing discipline meant service long after the sword was sheathed.
art: Lucilde rides with upright posture and controlled force, cloak and hair streaming into the frost-laden air. Her shield catches the last light of a fading sun, casting a pale reflection across the snow. The landscape around her feels harsh and ancient, yet her presence bends it toward purpose.

name: Mardun River Valley
flavor: Every spring that never came left its mark upon these waters
lore: In the final decades of the Ice Age, the Mardun marked the boundary between scattered warmth and deepening cold. Caravans followed its winding course to skirt the spirit-haunted forests of Fyndhorn, and Kjeldoran scouts swore that the river glowed faintly on moonless nights, as though it held the last memory of a sun that no longer rose.
art: The Mardun curves like a living vein through white wilderness, its banks littered with frost-kissed stones and lonely evergreens. Light sinks softly behind the mountains, turning the river’s surface into a ribbon of muted emerald that guides travelers toward distant Kjeldoran lands.

name: Mark of the Elder Druid
rules:
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2 and has vigilance and hexproof.
When enchanted creature dies, you may return another creature from your graveyard to play and attach this aura to it.
{3s}{Gs}{Ws}, Sacrifice Mark of the Elder Druid: Creatures you control gain indestructible until end of turn.
flavor: The mark chooses only those willing to carry the weight of the forest with a steady hand.
lore: During the waning years of the Ice Age, the title of Elder Druid fell to a man whose wisdom had been carved by hardship rather than ceremony. The crescent mark confirmed what his followers already knew—he was chosen not for power, but for restraint, compassion, and unfaltering resolve. While kingdoms clashed and necromancers rose, he preserved the fragile communion between elves, humans, and the sleeping spirit of the forest.
art: Snow drapes the ancient woods in muted silver, framing the Elder Druid’s weathered profile as if carved from the same winter that shaped him. The faint green crescent on his brow glows against the cold light, hinting at the quiet power he carries for the Juniper Order.

name: Meanders of Yavimaya River
rules:
Meanders of Yavimaya River enters play tapped unless you have a black creature and a black instant in your graveyard.
{Tn}: Add {Bs}{Bs}.
Black spells you cast cost {Bs} less to cast.
Nonsnow Swamps you control produce snow mana.
flavor: The thaw begins in whispers. The river is the first to speak.
lore: During the Ice Age, the Yavimaya River carved slow, luminous paths through the frozen valleys of southern Terisiare. Though distant from the great forests that would later bear its name, the river carried traces of ancient primal mana, drifting eastward from forgotten groves beyond the Shielded Sea. Even in the deepest winters, necromancers claimed the river’s winding channels dulled the boundaries between the living and the dead, making its meanders a favored haunt for black mages seeking subtle strength.
art: Twisting ribbons of dark water gleam beneath a sky heavy with stormlight, each curve glowing faintly as though lit from within. Snow-drowned banks stretch out in silence, their stillness broken only by the restless serpentine flow cutting through the frozen plain.

name: Mirror of True Nature
rules:
Snow permanents are no longer snow.
{1s}, {Tn}: Reveal the top card of your library. If it’s a land card, put it into play tapped. Otherwise, either mill or exile it.
{2s}, {Tn}: You gain 5 life.
{3s}, {Tn}: Put a planeswalker card from your hand, graveyard, or exile into play.
flavor:
“I show the world as it was, not as the cold has forced it to be.”
—Freyalise, Fyndhorn Goddess
lore: During the final years of the Ice Age, Freyalise carried Jodah’s mirror, a relic that reflected essence rather than image. Legends whispered that it displayed the world as it truly was before the long winter and could unmake illusions as easily as it revealed buried truths. The elves claimed Freyalise used it to read the strength of the land itself, testing whether Dominaria still had the will to thaw.
art: Moonlight threads through the bare branches as Freyalise studies the mirror’s living surface reflecting the true colors of nature before the Ice Age. Her face is calm and knowing, framed by wild auburn hair and the steady warmth of someone born to reshape the world rather than endure it. Her beauty carries an effortless natural grace, the strength of someone unbowed by the cold she commands.

name: Mirror of Yesterday
rules:
All creatures in play are Illusions instead of their usual creature types.
{1s}, {Tn}: Look at the top card of your library. You may exile it face down.
{1s}, {Tn}: You may play cards exiled with Mirror of Yesterday until end of turn.
{Bs}, {Tn}: Choose a card in your graveyard. You may play that card until end of turn.
flavor:
“Memory is a trick of the light. Truth is what you do with it.”
—Damon, Wizard before Time
lore: Damon’s first trial before the mirror ended in humiliation, his own image betraying him. But when death stalked the tower and his peers fell one by one, the same mirror became his salvation. By bending the assassin’s senses backward in time, he forced her into a fatal mistake and stepped fully into the wizard he already was.
art: Soft light coils around Damon’s silhouette, the mirror held delicately between his fingers as though weighing a secret he once knew. His earlier self lingers inside the glass, half-formed and patient, waiting for him to notice what was always there.

name: Mount Sarraza
rules:
Mount Sarraza enters play with five clock counters on it.
When you lose life, remove a clock counter from Mount Sarraza. When it has no clock counters on it, sacrifice it. Create a legendary 8/8 black and red Cockatrice creature token with flying and deathtouch named Beast of the Hours.
flavor: Where the sun bleeds over stone, the buried heartbeat of the Beast presses against the ice.
lore: During the long winter, Sarraza stood at the glacier’s border like a lone sentinel—cold, unbroken, and hiding an older terror beneath its roots. Songmage Samor’s ancient binding of the Beast of the Hours still thrummed through the stone, a quiet rhythm that only the mountain seemed patient enough to endure.
art: Sarraza stands illuminated by a dying sun, the sky burning behind it while frost clings to the stone. The scene carries a tension between beauty and restraint, as if the landscape itself is holding its breath, listening for the ticking heart sealed beneath.

name: New Sumifa
rules:
New Sumifa enters play tapped unless you control a Wizard or a Sphinx.
{Tn}: Add {Ws} or {Us} or {Cs}.
Walls you control get +3/+3, gain reach, and can attack as though they didn’t have defender.
{2s}, {Tn}: Draw a card, then discard a card.
flavor: Stone remembers every ruin. People remember only the ones that suit them.
lore: New Sumifa rose centuries after the first city was swallowed by desert winds and ambition. Wizards from the School of the Unseen shaped its defenses, weaving old tonal magics into its walls so the city would never again fall to pride or misplaced vengeance.
art: New Sumifa sprawls in precise concentric rings, each wall catching the last golden light of the day. Beyond its edges, frozen ridges and distant deserts act as reminder how precariously the city stands between its violent past and the cold that presses against it.

name: Northern Wastes
flavor: Walk far enough north and the world stops pretending to be alive.
lore: During the Ice Age, these wastes lay at the frayed edge of Lim-Dûl’s domain, a stretch of desert frozen into glassy death. The necromancer’s legions marched across it largely unhindered. Even after the Thaw, the land refused to heal, holding the memory of his reign like a wound that never closes.
art: Twilight spills over a landscape of frozen ash, the mountains sharp as broken spears. Melted patches glimmer like dying coals, hinting at long-quiet sorceries that left the earth half-burned, half-buried.

name: Null Moon
rules:
Snow permanents lose all abilities.
{Tn}: Add {Ws}{Us}{Cs}. Spend this mana only to cast legendary or artifact spells, and/or activate their abilities.
{3s}, {Tn}: Each player draws two cards.
{Tn}, Sacrifice Null Moon: Exile target legendary artifact or creature.
flavor: The sky remembers what Dominaria survived; the Null Moon is where those memories rest.
lore: The Null Moon began as a metallic citadel rooted in a mountain crater, its twin dishes drawing power from the land below and the firmament above. When its keepers shattered their chains and hurled it skyward, they left it to drift as a hollow guardian. Over millennia it filled with pale mana, a reservoir so dense that even the strongest enchantments faltered beneath its watch.
art: The Null Moon looms impossibly low above a barren tundra, its fractured shell glowing with the pale remnants of stored power. The land beneath it curves subtly inward, as if gravity itself remembers the crater that once anchored the sphere.

name: Oddveig Ulfsson
rules:
{Vigilance}`Vigilance`  {Horsemanship}`Horsemanship`
Non-animal creatures you control have protection from animal creatures.
Wolves you control get +1/+1 and gain lifelink.
You may play creature cards face down for {2s}{Gs} as 2/2 Wolf creatures with trample.
{Ws}{Gs}, {Tn}: Search your library for a Wolf creature and put it into play.
flavor: “I watch the road. The wolves watch everything else. That’s how we stay alive.”
lore: Oddveig Ulfsson earned his place among the Kjeldoran outriders by crossing the Frost Marsh alone and returning with a silent pack of wolves at his heels. The wolves of that tundra usually had nol patience for human hunters, yet something in Oddveig’s calm broke through their mistrust, so they followed him willingly to the ends of the world.
art: Far ahead of the caravan, Oddveig surveys the tundra with the practiced ease of someone who has heard every whisper the ice can make. The riders trail in his wake, confident not in numbers but in the unnerving certainty that he senses threats long before they break the frozen silhouette of the plains.

name: Ogwater Rifkin, Songmage
rules:
When an opponent casts a spell, you may exile the top card of their library. You may play that card next turn.
Whenever Ogwater Rifkin deals X combat damage to a player, scry X.
{Ws}{Us}{Bs}{Rs}, {Tn}: Untap target tapped creature. If you do, exile it.
flavor: “I never asked the world for a destiny. It just kept handing me trouble, so I started singing back.”
lore: The gemstones he claimed — from Rotapan’s bellowing orcs, Wiggulf’s selkies, Luquin’s healers, and Riolla’s ruthless syndicate — reshaped Ogwater into a conduit of competing magics. Songs learned in backalleys now harmonized with powers older than Almaaz itself. Those who heard him swear they felt their next decisions forming before they made them, as if the melody could skim futures still unwritten.
art: Robes billowing in the cold, Ogwater sings with fierce abandon, every gesture shaped by the rough grace of someone raised on rooftops and alley ledges. The night seems to lean in, listening, as if pulled by the cadence of an old Sumifan chronoclave.

name: Ohran Ridge
flavor: The wind remembers when the ice fled; the stone remembers when it ruled.
lore: The southwestern arm of the Colekgan Mountains outlasted the glaciers through sheer defiance of terrain, its ridges warmed by volcanic seams that the ice could not breach. When the glaciers receded, meltwater gathered in the basins below, and the region became a stark fusion of alpine heat and frozen beauty — a land shaped by two tempers at once.
art: Steep mountains rise in stark blue ridges around a basin of meltwater, the landscape shaped by ages of pressure and sudden release. The twin nature of the Ridge shows itself in the juxtaposition of warm stone and the cold stillness of the lake.

name: Ohran Sentinel
rules:
{Vigilance}`Vigilance`  {ProtectionB}`Protection from black`
Snow creatures you control have hexproof as long as Ohran Sentinel is untapped.
Whenever you gain life, put a +1/+1 counter on each snow creature you control.
If Ohran Sentinel would die in combat, instead exile it and all creatures blocking or blocked by it.
{Ws}{Ws},{Tn}: Return target snow creature that died this turn to play under your control.
flavor: When the Ridge calls for a guardian, it rises not from temples but from the mountain’s own silence.
lore: In the centuries after the Thaw, travelers spoke of a robed figure standing immobile on the cliffs, watching the valleys below. Tales spread that it was no mortal but an Ohran spirit of endurance, a knight-cleric woven from mountain resolve whose touch could restore any creature claimed by the cold.
art: The Sentinel waits upon a wind-scoured ledge, half-statue, half-spirit, its polished armor etched with motifs of the Ridge. Behind it, the mountains rise in jagged tiers, as though bowing to their guardian.

name: Ohran Shade
rules:
Snow creatures you control have fear, wither, and protection from nonsnow creatures.
{Ss}: Ohran Shade gets +2/+2 until end of turn.
When Ohran Shade deals damage to a player, they lose X life and you gain X life, where X is the number of snow permanents you control.
If Ohran Shade would die, exile it instead. At the next end step, return it to play tapped with a +1/+1 counter for each time it died.
flavor: Where the Ridge casts no shadow, one has already risen to take its place.
lore: When the glaciers withdrew from the Colekgan range, they left behind more than stone. In the darkest crevasses where ice had slept for centuries, a residue of cold mana thickened into restless spirits. The Ohran Shade is the eldest of these remnants — a predator shaped by silence, drawn to those who disturb the Ridge’s ancient equilibrium.
art: A tall, tattered silhouette rises against a swirling sky, its outline blurred by drifting frost. The mountains at its back seem carved from dusk, as if the Shade stepped forward directly from the Ohran Ridge’s oldest shadows.

name: Ohran Siren
rules:
{Flying}`Flying`  {ProtectionR}`Protection from red`
Whenever you cast a snow spell, you may tap target creature. It doesn’t untap during its controller’s next untap step.
{Ss}: Target creature attacks this turn if able.
{2s}{Ss}{Ss}, {Tn}: Gain control of target creature.
{3s}{Us}, {T}: Tap target permanent for each snow permanent you control.
flavor: The Ridge holds many dangers; she is the one that smiles as she takes you.
lore: Legends say a shard of the Null Moon once fell into an Ohran lagoon, infusing the water with uncanny resonance. From that mirror-bright pool emerged the first Siren — a being of shifting frost whose voice carries echoes of that ancient artifact. She drifts along cliff edges and frozen waters, drawing foes into patterns only she can unravel.
art: The Siren rises above the frost-scoured basin, her body sculpted from swirling ice and mist, every curve sharpened by the moon’s pale shimmer. Her expression is serene, inviting, while the air around her tightens with the quiet promise of control. Her blue-tinged form glows against the stark mountains, the cold light accentuating both her elegance and her threat. Wisps of frozen air wrap her like half-melted silk, giving her the presence of a winter goddess whose touch chills mind and body alike.

name: Oriel Kjeldos, Aesthir Tamer
rules:
Creatures with flying you control get +1/+0 and gain vigilance and lifelink.
When a creature with flying enters play, put a +1/+1 counter on it and on Oriel.
{2s}: Oriel gains flying until end of turn.
When Oriel dies, return all creatures with flying from your graveyard to play.
flavor: “Trust an Aesthir, and you’ll never walk alone. Fail it, and you’ll never walk again.”
lore: Oriel of Storgard was said to have tamed the first Aesthir, forging a bond strong enough to carry her clan safely through the fall of their citadel. Her teachings spread among the survivors, shaping the fledgling culture that would become Kjeldor. Generations later, her name remained a symbol of courage — a shaman who led her people by trusting what flew above when the ground failed them.
art: She leans forward with quiet authority, silver hair catching the twilight glow while the great bird watches her with solemn trust. Their shared stillness turns the snowy clearing into a moment of unspoken kinship.

name: Overking's Ajada
rules:
Creatures you control have ‘When this creature deals combat damage to a player, add {Rs} for each 1 damage dealt.’
{Tn}: Gain control of target Orc, Snake, Lizard, or Elemental. If it’s tapped, untap it. It gains haste.
{Xs}{Rs}, {Tn}: Ajada deals X damage divided as you choose among any targets.
flavor: Its fire obeys no master for long; it merely chooses the next to scorch.
lore: Once a jewel of the old Salamander cults, the Ajada was reforged by Wyrvil smiths into a war-staff whose crimson core pulsed with volcanic fury. Its magic could subdue beasts, ignite blood, and animate the forgotten dead. Rotapan wielded it as a symbol of rule — and as a promise that defiance would be met with fire. Though Og wrested it from the Wyrvil war party, its enchantments remain as volatile as the flame trapped within.
art: Rotapan’s silhouette rises from the frost, cloak billowing as the Ajada’s crimson light cuts through the gloom. The staff’s carved serpent flares with inner flame, illuminating the raw power coursing through its wielder.

name: Perena Deepcutter
rules:
{ProtectionS}`Protection from snow`  {Ward}`Ward` {5s}
Snow permanents lose all static abilities.
Perena Deepcutter gets +0/+1 for each other creature and artifact you control.
Sacrifice an artifact: Perena deals damage equal to that artifact’s mana value to any target. You gain that much life.
flavor: “If the snow wants a fight, it can step into my forge and say so.”
lore: Perena Deepcutter was one of the last armorsmiths of the Karplusan deeps, maintaining her forge long after the Yeti drove her kin into hiding. Stories say she kept the armory burning alone for years, dismantling relics and reforging them into weapons fit to carve through frost and beast alike. Her disdain for snow magic became legend — as did the artifacts she built to counter it.
art: The flicker of the fire catches her face as she hammers, revealing a woman carved by heat, stone, and war. Every line of her stance radiates competence — a lone smith holding the mountain against the cold.

name: Pharon, Kjeldoran Wizard
rules:
Creatures with flying you control get +1/+1 and gain ward {2s} and hexproof from instants.
Whenever a creature with flying attacks, you may tap or untap up to 2 target permanents.
{4s}{Ws}{Us}{Rs}, {Tn}, Exile Pharon: Destroy all nonland permanents. If they have indestructible, they lose that ability until end of turn. You gain life equal to the number of permanents destroyed this way.
