flavor: “History is a fire. Best you learn to control it before it decides to control you.”
lore: Pharon’s long life was sustained less by magic than by purpose: guarding Kjeldor from repeating the catastrophes that forged it. His mastery of sky-currents, frost-wards, and Sylex lore earned him reverence — and fear. As his strength faded, he revealed to his successor the spell he had never dared cast, a final safeguard carved from Urza’s most terrible memory.
art: Pharon stands in a dim stone hall, robes flowing like drifting snow as a spiral of pale magic coils from his staff. The candles behind him tremble, as though aware of the deep knowledge he carries.

name: Porros, the Sand Wraith
rules:
{Flying}`Flying`  {Wither}`Wither`  {Haste}`Haste`
Spirits you control have Desert landwalk.
If Porros becomes the target of a spell, copy that spell and choose new targets for it.
{Rs}{Ws}{Bs}, {Tn}: Target basic land is a Desert.
Whenever Porros, the Sand Wraith deals damage to a player, return target land that player controls to its owner’s hand.
flavor: In every dune lies a grain of the city he buried — and of the life he lost.
lore: The transformation stripped Porros of human flesh but not of memory. As the Sand Wraith, he drifted above the ruins of Sumifa, an immortal tethered to a graveyard of his own making. Travelers spoke of a crimson-cloaked figure whose touch drained vitality and whose voice carried the fury of three thousand years. They feared him less as a monster and more as a warning.
art: He rises above the desert floor, cloak whipping in the gale as the dunes twist and recoil beneath him. His features blur into grit and shadow, only the pale eyes remaining — a remnant of the man buried with Sumifa.

name: Ravidel the Dragon Keeper
rules:
{Menace}`Menace`  {Lifelink}`Lifelink`  {Ward}`Ward` {3s}
If Ravidel would leave play, return him to play tapped during the next upkeep.
At your end step, if you attacked this turn, you gain 2 life, if not, you may scry 2.
{2s}, {Tn}: Put a counter on target permanent that already has counters on it; or remove a counter from target permanent.
flavor: “Rhuell doesn’t obey me. He trusts me. That’s worth more than any spell Faralyn ever taught me.”
lore: Before bitterness warped him, Ravidel served as Faralyn’s spellsquire, charged with tending the Elder Dragonling Chromium Rhuell. Exiled from his dying homeland and furious at the injustice of it, he found unexpected solace in the creature’s company. Their bond grew from necessity into genuine friendship, and together they aided Faralyn in unraveling the strange physics of the Shard.
art: Ravidel stands at the dragonling’s side as dawn breaks over the frozen flats, his posture equal parts awe and resolve. Rhuell’s wings catch the cold light, arching protectively behind him as if acknowledging their growing bond.

name: Ravidel, Collector of Lives
rules:
+2: Return target nonland permanent to its owner’s hand. If that permanent had enchantments or counters on it, draw a card.
-X: Target player sacrifices a creature with mana value X. You may put loyalty counters on Ravidel equal to that creature’s power.
-11: Opponents discard their hands. Each player’s maximum hand size becomes zero. Players can’t draw more than 1 card each turn.
flavor: “Every soul is a lesson. Some I study. Some I savor.”
lore: Resurrected with a raw, unstable spark, Ravidel rose from the Null Moon seething with grief for Rhuell and hatred for Faralyn. Taysir found the broken youth and forged him into a disciplined, dangerously gifted planeswalker. Yet every lesson only sharpened the hunger for vengeance burning in him. By the time of the Summit of Minorad, his power and ambition no longer resembled those of the boy who once cared for a dragon.
art: Ravidel stands bare-chested amid swirling snow, his hair whipped white by the gale as crimson light coils around his fist. His expression is exultant, half laughter and half threat — a creature reveling in the moment before devastation.

name: Ravidel's Planar Barge
rules:
{Flying}`Flying`  {Trample}`Trample`
Planeswalkers you control have hexproof and can’t be attacked.
{1s}: Exile target permanent you control. Return it to play during the next upkeep.
If Planar Barge would die, exile it instead. Return it to play at the next end step with a -1/-1 counter for each time it’s died.
flavor:
“Cold hull, colder master. It carries only those who have already left the living behind.”
—Kristina of the Woods
lore: Forged during the early years after his resurrection, the Planar Barge was Ravidel’s first attempt at shaping a vessel worthy of a planeswalker. Its skeletal frame was a reminder of what he had lost on the Null Moon, and its drifting flight let him traverse the Shard with ruthless efficiency. Before Minorad, it became both transport and weapon — a silent omen announcing that Ravidel had arrived.
art: The dragon-vessel floats just above the tundra, its ribs stretched into the shape of wings and its skull lit with ember-blue light, as though animated by a distant storm.

name: Raynor Glacier
rules:
{Tn}: Add {Us}. If you control another snow permanent, add {Us} or {Bs} instead.
{Tn}: Add {Cs}{Cs}. Spend this mana only to cast artifact and/or snow spells.
{Us}{Bs}, {Tn}: Target creature gets -X/-0 until end of turn, where X equals the number of snow permanents in play.
flavor: Storgard did not fall—it was swallowed.
lore: The glacier’s advance erased Storgard from the map, leaving a jagged, haunted expanse where wind howled through the remnants of a drowned kingdom. Deep inside, the Labyrinth of Raynor coiled with black mana amassed by Szat’s agent, its presence warping the ice around it. At the twilight of the Ice Age, Jaeuhl Carthalion ventured into that frozen maze and emerged carrying the Amulet of Quoz—and scars no warmth could melt.
art: The glacier stretches to the horizon, crossed by deep chasms glowing faintly from within. Winds sweep powdered snow into spirals that vanish down into the abyss.

name: Rigida
rules: {BL2} {BL2} {Snowwalk} {Trample} {Vigilance} {Indestructible} {Wither}
flavor: “We carved kingdoms out of winter before mortals learned to fear the cold.”
lore: The Rigida rose with the first great freeze, shaping a Glacial Kingdom across Almaaz while mortal nations faltered beneath the sudden cold. Humanoid in form but wrought of ancient ice, they sculpted towers, halls, and armies from frost itself. Their reign endured for millennia until the Thaw fractured their dominion and left only scattered remnants of their former power.
art: The elemental rises from the frost like a sculpture waking, her translucent form catching the cold sunlight. Jagged ice along her arms and hips marks her as both beautiful and perilous, a living shard of the Glacial Kingdom.

name: Rimewind Keep
rules:
Rimewind Keep enters play tapped.
{Tn}: Add {Us} or {Bs} or {Cs}.
{1s}{Ss}: Tap target creature.
{2s}{Ss}, {Tn}: Exile target tapped creature.
{1s}{Us}{Bs}, {Tn}: Return target permanent from exile to play under your control. It’s a snow artifact in addition to its other types.
flavor:
“The ice is not our prison—it’s our scripture.”
—Gendrin, Rimewind Keeper
lore: Built near the Ronom Glacier, the Keep began as a scholarly refuge where cryomancers learned to shape mana through frozen strata. As fear of summer drove Heidar to delve into the vaults below, the Keep became a crucible of forbidden learning—its chambers etched with Phyrexian script and its ice lattices warped by madness. Long after the cult’s fall, echoes of those experiments seep upward, thin as frost breath.
art: The fortress looms from the glacier rim, sculpted not by hands alone but by centuries of ritual shaping. Blue light pulses through its inner seams, suggesting the echo of the Phyrexian-etched chambers hidden below.

name: Ring of Mairsil
rules:
You may activate abilities of exiled cards as though those cards were in play.
{Bs}{Bs}{Bs}, {Tn}: Return target creature from a graveyard to play under your control. It’s a Zombie in addition to its other types.
{Tn}, Sacrifice this artifact: Gain control of target legendary creature or planeswalker. If it’s a creature, it gains haste.
flavor: A whisper preserved in ruby, patient enough to outlive faith, kingdoms, and sanity.
lore: Mairsil had woven his soul into the ruby during the collapse of the Conclave, trusting that time and frost would deliver him a vessel worthy of possession. The long winter obliged. Lim-Dûl’s touch awakened the Pretender’s lingering intellect, and with it came old tricks—enslaved minds, stolen memories, and a whispering promise that the Ice Age could be molded into a reign of unending dominion.
art: The ruby glows like a coal preserved against the cold, its light hinting at the consciousness sealed within. The shadowed figure behind it feels half-manifested, as if the Ice Age itself is struggling to recall the Pretender’s shape.

name: Riolla Hifrata
rules:
{Deathtouch}`Deathtouch`  {Ward}`Ward`—Pay 3 life.
Whenever a player gains control of a permanent you own, that player loses life equal to that permanent’s mana value and you draw a card.
When you cast a multicolored spell, exile a spell from any graveyard. You may cast it this turn.
When Riolla dies, target opponent gains control of a nonland permanent you control at random, and you gain two of theirs at random.
flavor: “I don’t steal fortunes. I simply show people what their greed already promised me.”
lore: As the snows retreated from Almaaz, wealth flooded through the city’s reopened passes, drawing parasites, prophets, and opportunists. Riolla ruled the merchant caste by mastering all three roles at once. Her influence reached from Sumifa’s silks to the wind-carved ruins of Sarraza, where she chased legends not for glory but for leverage over anyone foolish enough to oppose her.
art: The alleyway is carved from dark stone, yet she commands it effortlessly, her silhouette warm against the creeping chill. Her posture—hips angled slightly, shoulders poised—suggests someone accustomed to bending others to her rhythm. Even the faint light feels drawn to her, as if Almaaz itself yields to her ambition.

name: River Kingdom of Selkies
rules:
Elves and Merfolk you control get +2/+2 and gain all abilities of non-Elf non-Merfolk creatures in play.
Islands you control are also Forests, and vice versa.
{Gs}{Us}, {Tn}: Target creature is a Merfolk in addition to its other types.
flavor: Where river and forest share a pulse, shapes shift, songs rise, and kingdoms are born from water’s memory.
lore: Formed after the Flooding of Terisiare split Almaaz from the Borderlands, the River Kingdom blossomed in the warm flow of the Sarrazan River. Here, selkie shapeshifters forged an enduring peace with the valley elves, sharing waters, harvests, and protective rites. Drufalden’s cold sorcery once threatened to freeze their domain into silence, but Ogwater Rifkin’s thawing song restored the river’s voice—and the Selkies reclaimed their shifting legacy.
art: The turquoise basin stands out against the frost—an oasis carved by meltwater and kept alive by the Selkies’ presence. Below the crystalline surface, their shapes glide through shadow and sunlit refractors, merging elegant human lines with fluid beast forms. The surrounding pines seem to bow toward the refuge, as if guarding the last untouched breath of the Sarrazan River.

name: Rotapan, Overking of Wyrvil
rules:
{FirstStrike}`First strike`  {Menace}`Menace`
Whenever a creature you control dies, put a Bone counter on Rotapan. He gets +1/+0 for each Bone counter on him.
At your end step, if Rotapan has five or more Bone counters on him, sacrifice Rotapan. Create a legendary 10/10 blue and black Serpent Drake creature token with flying and trample named Lord Chelydrus.
flavor: “My crown’s not forged of gold. It’s carved from everyone who said I couldn’t wear it.”
lore: Born  in the brutal pits of Wyrvil, Rotapan clawed upward through mockery and blood, outliving every usurper who mistook his size for frailty. By the height of the Thaw, he ruled the southern bone-palaces overlooking the Silver Sea, his floors layered with trophies of rivals whose spirits he bound inside a gem-tipped scepter. His worship of Chelydrus, the ancient serpent drake, shaped both his rituals and his ruthlessness.
art: Rotapan stands against a storm-lit sky, muscles taut beneath fur and leather armor, the bone-tipped scepter raised like a victory banner. Snow whirls around him as if driven back by sheer force of will.

name: Royal Academy of Magic
rules:
Whenever you cast an instant or a sorcery, draw a card, then pay any amount of mana.
For each {Ws} you pay, exile the top card of your library. You may play it this turn.
For each {Us}{Us} you pay, copy the spell you cast and choose new targets for the copy.
For each {Bs} you pay, each opponent discards a card or sacrifices a nonland permanent.
flavor: Every empire keeps a beacon. Kjeldor kept a tower whose shadow taught mages how far the fall could reach.
lore: Raised above the rooftops of Krov, the Royal Academy served as Kjeldor’s public bastion of sorcery, a counterweight to the hidden workings of Lat-Nam. Gustha Ebbasdotter guided its scholars during the harshest centuries of the Ice Age, shaping spellcraft suited to frozen battlefields and glacier-lit nights. But after Lim-Dûl’s assault and Gustha’s death, the Academy fractured into rival sects whose quarrels mirrored the Thaw itself—slow, inevitable dissolution.
art: A fortress of knowledge stands against the horizon, its towers catching the last cold shimmer of the sun. Snow gathers at the base of its foundations, yet the architecture speaks of confidence—an age when Kjeldor believed knowledge alone could outmatch necromancy and rising night.

name: Ruins of Argoth
flavor: Among the waves, the forest endures—not whole, but still alive enough to grieve.
lore: The Sylex Blast shattered Argoth into scattered islets—basalt teeth rising from the sea, each crowned with the last stubborn remnants of Titania’s forest. During the Ice Age, the region lay numbed beneath glacial winds, yet strange growth persisted in sheltered crags where ancient magic clung to stone. A few elven survivors tended these fragments until Fyndhorn’s thawing forests offered them refuge centuries later.
art: The shoreline is a ruin of splintered cliffs and half-drowned groves, the ocean heaving against remnants of a world destroyed. Pale sky and restless water frame the lonely spires, where a few wind-bent trunks cling to life. The scene feels haunted—less by ghosts than by the land itself remembering its own destruction.

name: Ruins of Old Sumifa
rules:
{Tn}: Add {Ws}, {Us}, {Bs}, or {Cs}. Ruins of Old Sumifa deals 1 damage to you.
{2s}, {Tn}: Mill two cards, then return a card from your graveyard to your hand.
{3s}{Ws}{Bs}, {Tn}, Sacrifice Ruins of Old Sumifa: Return target legendary creature card from your graveyard to play tapped.
flavor: Old Sumifa lies silent—yet every stone still listens for a song that will never return.
lore: Old Sumifa fell when Porros, twisted into a sand wraith by Samor’s curse, unleashed a spiral storm that entombed the city beneath the desert. For centuries it remained forgotten, its songmages’ halls muffled under shifting dunes. When the Thaw reached southern Almaaz, erosion and excavation exposed the ancient rings of the city once more, revealing relics touched by Caelus Nin.
art: Snow-dusted sandstone rises above a crater of concentric ruins, the excavated rings revealing Old Sumifa’s once-harmonic design. The pale sun casts long shadows across broken corridors, giving the impression of a city that collapsed mid-song.

name: Saffi Eriksdotter
rules:
{Vigilance}`Vigilance`  {Lifelink}`Lifelink`  {Haste}`Haste`
As long as there are more creatures in play than in your graveyard, Saffi has indestructible.
Whenever another creature you control would die, you may sacrifice Saffi Eriksdotter instead.
At your end step, if you control no creatures, return Saffi Eriksdotter from your graveyard to play tapped. She gains Shadow and is a Spirit in addition to her other types.
flavor: “Balduvians don’t die quietly. We die buying someone else a chance.”
lore: Raised in a clan where courage mattered more than strength, Saffi excelled at moving swiftly across frozen terrain and reading danger in the hush of snow. During a routine sweep with Hans, a Lhurgoyf erupted from the drifted undergrowth. Saffi intervened, drawing its hunger toward herself so her brother could flee to warn the village. Later generations whispered that Saffi’s shade roamed the night paths, watching over those who walked alone.
art: Saffi’s figure cuts sharply against the cold greens and silvers of the forest, her posture balanced between speed and alertness. Muscles coil beneath her winter leathers, built for survival rather than display, though the confidence in her movement carries its own unmistakable allure.

name: Sages of Minorad
rules:
#`The Gathering` — When you control three or more non-animal creatures and/or planeswalkers, the following abilities are in effect:#
Planeswalkers you own gain ‘+1: Draw a card.’
Whenever you cast a noncreature spell, you may scry 3 and then draw two cards.
Whenever a legendary permanent enters play under your control, you may return a permanent from your graveyard to play.
flavor: Five sparks met upon the summit—enough light to cast shadows through ages.
lore: Minorad’s spires became a beacon in the late Ice Age, drawing thinkers, mystics, and planeswalkers to a summit where knowledge transcended nations and lifetimes. The Gathering marked the dawn of a new chronology—but envy and vengeance followed swiftly. Ravidel’s attack forced the Sages into exile or bondage. Though scattered, they later reunited to help destroy the Sylex, ensuring that Minorad’s legacy was not lost to silence.
art: Sages approach the crystalline citadel rising from the arctic dusk, its spire framed by a vast ring of shimmering light. Snow-swept ridges surround the summit like silent witnesses to the Gathering. The energy halo suggests the merging of immense intellects—and the danger such brilliance invites.

name: Samiks, the Marked One
rules:
{Vigilance}`Vigilance`  {Lifelink}`Lifelink`  {Wither}`Wither`
During your upkeep, put a plague counter on Samiks. When he has four or more plague counters, sacrifice him.
Samiks has hexproof and indestructible as long as he has a plague counter on him.
When Samiks dies, search your library for an artifact card and a legendary creature. Put one into play and the other into your hand.
flavor: “Steel holds the body. Purpose holds everything else.”
lore: In the deep Ice Age, Samiks was one of Balduvia’s Marked Ones—those doomed by plague who chose service over surrender. Stricken but unbroken, he carried warnings of Lim-Dûl’s poisoned waters across a land locked in frost. When his strength failed, he hung himself upright from a tree so Kailo and Zaraya would find him as a warrior still on duty. With his final breath, he entrusted them with the Nova Pentacle, ensuring his message outlived him.
art: Samiks stands in brittle winter light, armor etched with the frost that clings to the dying. His red cloak breaks the monochrome of snow and plague-pale skin, hinting at the fire of a life pushed past its limits. Bare trees frame the cold resolve in his stance, as though even the forest mourns but respects him.

name: Samor's Chronoclave
rules:
When this artifact enters play, exile target creature with power 3 or more.
Whenever a creature would enter play from a graveyard or exile, exile it instead.
If Samor’s Chronoclave becomes untapped outside your untap step, sacrifice it. When you do, exile all artifacts and destroy all creatures.
flavor:
“Time remembers what men forget. Especially their mistakes.”
—Ogwater Rifkin, Songmage
lore: Samor forged the Chronoclave in desperation, weaving his daughter’s namesong into a lattice of resonant time-magic to contain the Beast of the Hours. When Porros betrayed him and Sumifa fell beneath the sands, the Chronoclave endured, preserved in the silent ruin beneath the desert crust. Three millennia later, Ogwater Rifkin found it and unwound Samor’s final harmonics, releasing the trapped spell that saved Almaaz.
art: The Chronoclave rests in a ring of broken stone, its suspended orbs glowing with the soft pulse of trapped song. Faint ripples of light spiral through the cold air, as if the air itself remembers the rhythm that once stilled a monster beneath a mountain.

name: Samor's Skeleton
rules:
Legendary spells you cast cost {2s} less to cast.
Spells cast from graveyards cost {Bs}{Bs} more.
Whenever you cast a legendary or a noncreature spell, add {Cs}{Cs} and gain 3 life.
During your upkeep, if you control Samor’s Chronoclave, Samor’s Skeleton becomes a 9/9 Skeleton Spirit artifact creature with flying and indestructible until end of turn.
flavor:
“The desert kept his bones; the song kept his purpose.”
—Claria the Cartographer
lore: When the sands consumed Sumifa, Samor died beneath the storm he tried to prevent. His skeleton lay preserved under the buried ruins for three millennia, a silent anchor for the song-magic he wove into the Chronoclave. When Ogwater discovered the ruins, the harmonics bound to Samor’s remains awakened once more.
art: The skeleton lies untouched by scavengers, its posture strangely serene. The surrounding desert is cracked with ancient spell-light, hinting that the bones still hum with the magic that once saved Almaaz.

name: Sarrazan Fire-Bane
rules:
Prevent all noncombat damage that would be dealt to creatures you control.
Whenever a creature you control is dealt combat damage, put that many +1/+1 counters on it at the next end step.
{1s}, {Tn}: Choose one — Remove all -1/-1 counters from target creature; or remove all poison counters from target player.
flavor:
“Elves carry it as balm; traitors seek it as a weapon.”
—Wiggulf, Selkies Waterking
lore: In the age when the Sarrazan River narrowed to threads of ice, the Elves guarded the Fire-Bane as a healing beacon. Its warmth countered the fire-magic Riolla’s conspirators hoped to unleash across Almaaz. After reclaiming the gem, the Elves entrusted it to Ogwater, knowing his path entangled with forces seeking to unravel the Borderlands.
art: The Fire-Bane glows like a captive sunrise, its fractured surface pulsing gently against the encroaching cold. Moss and ice cling to its stone outcrop, caught between winter’s grip and the relic’s ancient warmth.

name: Sarrazan River
rules:
If there is a snow land in play, Sarrazan River enters play tapped.
{Tn}: Add {Gs} or {Us}. If you control an Elf or a Merfolk, add {Gs}{Us} instead.
{Gs}{Us}: Target green or blue creature gets +2/+2 and gains islandwalk and forestwalk until end of turn.
flavor: Even when ice breaks and kingdoms drown, the Sarrazan River still keeps its melody.
lore: The Sarrazan River wound beneath Mount Sarraza long before the Ice Age’s advance, its current guiding Samor to the hidden valley of the Chimes where he shaped the spell that imprisoned the Beast of the Hours. Even as the Great Glacier pressed near, the river carved a narrow refuge that later blossomed into the River Kingdom. When the Thaw flooded Terisiare, its course became a boundary between the fractured Borderlands and Almaaz.
art: Mount Sarraza rises in sharp silhouettes while the river spills through the valley in shimmering bends. Frost gathers at the edges, but the water runs lively—an unbroken melody in a frozen world.

name: Sea of Almaaz
rules:
{Tn}: Add {Us}. If at least half of lands you control are Islands, add {Us}{Us} instead. Tap target snow permanent.
{Us}, {Tn}: Destroy target snow enchantment or noncreature artifact.
{Us}{Us}, {Tn}: Destroy target snow creature.
{Us}{Us}{Us}, {Tn}: Destroy target snow land.
flavor: When the Thaw carved a wound through Terisiare the sea moved in to claim it.
lore: The Sea of Almaaz was born not from storm or tectonic fury, but from the slow surrender of the world’s oldest ice. As Terisiare fractured during the Thaw, the meltwater carved channels between Almaaz and Gulmany, flooding the plains and erasing the last landmarks linking those realms.
art: The sea shines with the strange clarity of newborn waters, its turquoise depths still settling over the drowned traces of old Almaaz. Jagged cliffs stand guard like broken teeth from a lost frontier, their frosted edges hinting at how recently the glaciers withdrew.

name: Sea of Laments
rules:
Sea of Laments enters play tapped unless you control five or more Islands and/or Swamps.
{Tn}: Add {Us} or {Bs}. If you control no other legendary lands, add {Us}{Bs} instead.
When a snow land leaves play, draw a card.
{2s}{Us}{Bs}, {Tn}: Return target creature or artifact card from your graveyard to your hand. If it’s legendary, return it to play tapped instead.
flavor: Beneath its waves lie all the questions the Thaw never answered.
lore: Born from the final surrender of Terisiare’s glaciers, the Sea of Laments drowned the Boreal, Tresserhorn, and Frost Marsh beneath cold, rising tides. Its waters spread across the Northern Wastes and old Adarkar pathways, linking the broken realms into the Terisian Isles. In those first unsettled years, mages of the School of the Unseen crossed its forming shores, guiding survivors from lands vanishing under the flood.
art: The coastline slopes toward a deep blue vastness, where rough waves pound against cliffs half-claimed by the rising sea. The dim, veiled moon casts silvery paths across waters that once covered snowfields and tundra. Everything in view feels newly made, but heavy with old sorrow.

name: Silver Sea
rules:
{Tn}: Add {Cs}{Us}{Us}. Spend this mana only to cast snow spells and/or activate abilities of snow permanents.
{Tn}, Put a counter on target permanent that already has counters on it: Return target creature to its owner’s hand.
{Tn}, Sacrifice Silver Sea: All lands are nonsnow Islands until end of turn.
flavor: Where the ice ruled without mercy, the sea learned to shimmer like metal.
lore: The Silver Sea first formed when Drufalen froze the Borderlands into her austere winter domain, shrinking the Sarrazan River and lowering the coasts around her kingdom. Cut off from the ocean, the trapped waters turned brackish and strange, home to creatures marooned by the Thaw. Rotapan built his half-orc realm along its edge, venerating the elusive drake Chelydrus that prowled its depth. Only Ogwater Rifkin’s song would break Drufalen’s hold, sending a final tide that drowned the sea into the Lat-Nam Straits.
art: Vast plates of frozen sea stretch outward like polished steel, broken only by cliffs that sink into the shimmering white expanse. The light above feels cold and watchful, as if Drufalen’s lingering sorcery still clings to the horizon.

name: Soldev
rules:
{Tn}: Add {Us}.
{Us}{Us}{Us}, {Tn}: Target opponent searches your library for a blue permanent and puts it into play under your control.
{Tn}, #Blizzard# — Exile Soldev until end of turn: Islands you control become snow and deal 1 damage to any target when tapped for mana during a #Blizzard#.
flavor: Steel obeyed, steam hissed, and Soldev thrived—until its own creations answered a different call.
lore: Soldev’s machinists built their city as a living mechanism—fountains timed to chiming clocks, needle-thin spires stitched together by metal struts, and Steam Beasts that patrolled like tireless sentinels. But the Soldevi Adnates twisted that precision into something darker, binding Phyrexian designs to local craft. When the constructs turned on Arcum Dagsson’s guild, the betrayal shattered the city’s order. Jaya Ballard’s awakening firestorm erased what remained.
art: The city glows with the muted sheen of worked metal and clean stone, its towers tapering like polished instruments toward the pale light. Activity stirs in the wide avenue below—bundled figures moving past chimneys and wintered workshops. There’s an orderly beauty to it all, a sense that every structure belongs to a vast, unseen mechanism.

name: Sorine Relicbane
rules:
Artifact and enchantment spells cast by your opponents enter play tapped.
Creatures you control have protection from artifacts and enchantments.
{4s}, {Tn}, Sacrifice Sorine: Exile up to three artifacts from target opponent’s library.
{3s}, {Tn}: Destroy target artifact.
flavor: “I don’t hate inventions. I hate the arrogance that builds them without listening to history.”
lore: Once a prodigy of the machinist guilds, Sorine watched Arcum Dagsson’s fascination with old war-constructs grow into a risk he could not ignore. His warnings about Phyrexian remnants were dismissed as paranoia, and the Adnates’ interference only deepened the danger. When Soldev fell to its own creations, survivors whispered that Sorine had been the lone voice truly listening to Terisiare’s scars.
art: Clad in rugged layers stitched with Soldev’s precise metalwork, Sorine faces the horizon with the stern confidence of someone who’s survived too many lessons. The broken ice around him hints at the collapse of the mechanical ideals he once embraced. His expression carries the weary certainty of a dissenting craftsman proven right too late.

name: Steinar Icefist
rules:
{Reach}`Reach`  {HexproofR}`Hexproof from red`
{Us}{Us}, {Tn}: Counter target activated ability. Put a +1/+1 counter on Steinar.
{Xs}{Rs}, {Tn}: Steinar Icefist deals X damage divided among up to X targets. Draw a card for each target destroyed this way. If a snow creature is destroyed this way, Steinar Icefist gains flying.
flavor: “I call the storm by name, and it answers like an old friend eager for trouble.”
lore: Legends place Steinar among the mountain shamans who stood watch during the Ice Age’s fiercest winters, trading whispers with storm elementals that prowled the skies. His mastery over snow-spirits and wind-devils made him a guide to wandering clans, and a nightmare to raiders who underestimated a shaman’s reach. Many claim that the spirits lent him their power only because he treated them as equals, not tools.
art: The broad-shouldered shaman faces the horizon, his beard whipped by the winds he commands. The ember-lit staff in his grasp casts long shadows across fractured ice, hinting at the raw elemental forces braided into his rites. Behind him, distant peaks fade into mist—haunts of the spirits he calls by name.

name: Storgard
rules:
{Tn}: Add one mana of any color among permanents you control.
{3s}, {Tn}: Add {Ws}{Us}{Bs}{Rs}{Gs}.  Activate if you control permanents of 5 different colors.
{5s}, {Tn}: Reveal the top five cards of target library. You may put a card of each color from among them into your hand. Put the rest in the corresponding graveyard.
flavor: Storgard’s five banners fell in five different ways—yet the ice claimed them with perfect fairness.
lore: Storgard was a kingdom of five clans, each a color of power, each certain the others needed “guidance.” Raynor Glacier didn’t care—its slow judgment erased pride and charity alike, leaving only what was hidden well and remembered harder. Lim-Dûl’s storms and Tevesh Szat’s cruelty finished what the ice began. The survivors walked southeast to what later became Kjeldor; while the opportunists returned and named the rubble Soldev.
art: Storgard rises like a clenched fist of stone in the Sardian Mountains—spires stabbing upward as if defying Raynor Glacier itself. Emberlit windows and faint smoke mark the last stubborn warmth of the five clans, surrounded by a silence that feels ancient and unimpressed. A small burn-glow clings to one tower—history refusing, briefly, to go quietly.

name: Summit of the Null Moon
rules:
Target player sacrifices a legendary permanent or a creature with mana value five or more.
Exile all permanents that entered play last turn or earlier this turn.
Exile all permenents that will enter play later this turn or next turn.
flavor: The Null Moon heard their speeches, weighed their intentions—and erased the parts that mattered.
lore: The Summit was sold as cooperation, yet it became selection—who remains, who vanishes, who never gets the chance to matter. Leshrac and Tevesh Szat didn’t need victory; they needed a moment clean enough to harvest, and the Null Moon provided it with merciless elegance. Chromium Rhuell’s death cracked the air with usable power, and the aftermath left the living rearranged into sharper, lonelier shapes. Ravidel’s resurrection became a wound that wouldn’t close, and Freyalise’s resolve hardened into something vast, patient, and final.
art: The Null Moon hangs like a wound in the sky, its luminous rim framing a serpentine presence that feels less summoned than remembered. Cloaked planeswalkers form a tense perimeter, spaced like witnesses who don’t trust the testimony they’re about to give. The empty distance around them makes the scene feel ceremonial—because here, ceremony is just cruelty with better posture.

name: Taaveti of Kelsinko
rules:
{Vigilance}`Vigilance`  {Reach}`Reach`  {Haste}`Haste`
When Taaveti enters play, search your library for a snow land and put it into play.
Creature spells you cast can’t be countered.
Other creatures you control have protection from blue and black.
{Tn}: Target Human gains first strike, haste, vigilance, or reach until end of turn.
flavor: “Kjeldoran steel is brave. It just needs a forest to teach it where bravery belongs.”
lore: Taaveti of Kelsinko was a Fyndhorn hunter who treated the Ice Age like a living map—patient, exacting, and unforgiving to fools. He guided Lucilde Fiksdotter and the Order of the White Shield, and later led Vannemir through peril on a rescue that could not afford delay. Even among the Juniper Order and their human allies, he remained a native of Fyndhorn first—loyal, but never fully at home outside its old breath. In the war between New Argive and the Cult of Rimewind, a Deathmark found him, and the forest lost one of its surest footsteps.
art: Taaveti stands deep in the Fyndhorn forest as if the trees are an ally taking his side—fur at his shoulders, bow in hand, eyes set on a trail only he can read. His gear is practical, worn, and lovingly maintained—the look of someone who’s guided too many humans past their own confidence. The quiet around him feels earned, not given, like the world is holding its breath out of respect.

name: Taysir of Rabiah
rules:
+1: Reveal the top two cards of your library. You may put one of them into your hand and the rest on the bottom of your library.
-2: Choose one — Exile target permanent that entered play last turn; or exile target permanent when it will enter play next turn.
-10: Taysir deals damage to each creature equal to the number of colors opponents have in play. Draw a card for each creature that dies.
flavor: “I have worn five selves like five blades; the Shard only taught me which one cuts cleanest.”
lore: Taysir’s Ice Age is a chain of almosts: almost breaking the Shard at the Summit, almost stopping the deaths that fueled others’ escape, almost keeping love intact once the multiverse reopened. He survived the Null Moon’s cold calculus and helped restore Ravidel, only to earn rage in return. When the World Spell ended the Ice Age, Kristina chose the open horizon over Rabiah’s sealed forever. Taysir chose pride, purpose, and the long ache of wanting.
art: Taysir, a robed figure framed by a swirling crown of radiance, hinting at the Thousandfold Refraction’s legacy—many selves braided into one will. He looks upward as if weighing a crossing, measuring distance by instinct rather than hope. The scene feels suspended between departure and a home that won’t open.

name: Tevesh Szat, Silent Death
flavor: “Mercy is a lullaby for fools. I brought Dominaria something truer—silence.”
lore: After the Shard of Twelve Worlds closed, Tevesh Szat kept to his vow of “silence,” erasing kingdoms because he believed they only ripened into corruption. He nudged the clash between Freyalise and Jason Carthalion until Storgard was mortally wounded, then watched the ice finish the argument. With Leshrac he patroned Lim-Dûl, feeding the necromancer’s war against Kjeldor like a slow, deliberate plague. At the Summit of the Null Moon he fought among the gods, then slipped away to keep the winter tightening—until Jaeuhl Carthalion broke his momentum and forced him into flight.
art: A draconic silhouette fills the sky like a thought you can’t unthink—horns, wings, and a lean brutality shaped into certainty. The red eyes are the only warmth, and they don’t offer it; they measure what’s worth ending. He isn’t roaring—he’s simply present, and the air around him feels quieter because of it.

name: Thangbrand Gyrdsson
rules:
{Vigilance}`Vigilance`  {Snowwalk}`Snow landwalk`
Whenever a creature dies, you may exile it instead. If you do, you gain 2 life and put a patrol counter on Thangbrand Gyrdsson.
During your upkeep, reveal X cards from the top of your library where X equals the number of patrol counters on Thangbrand Gyrdsson. You may choose an instant or sorcery card among them and put it into your hand.
flavor: “Snow hides the mess for a day. My job is making sure it stays hidden forever.”
lore: Kjeldoran patrols didn’t just watch borders; they watched the aftermath, where Lim-Dûl’s kind and worse things made use of the forgotten. Thangbrand built a ritual habit of denial—no grave, no monument, no second chances for the dead to stand back up. The work hardened him into that dry, bitter humor soldiers grow when they’d rather laugh than freeze. The more he cleared, the more he learned what trouble looks like before it arrives.
art: Thangbrand crouches alone on a blank white field, sword planted like a boundary marker—less a pose of rest than of watchfulness. The set of his shoulders says he’s counting routes, not seconds, and the emptiness around him feels like a case file he’s already solved. Even the ground looks “cleaned,” as if nothing is allowed to linger.

name: The White Veil
rules:
When The White Veil enters play, target opponent discards a card for each veiled creature in play. #(Veiled creature is a creature with artwork depicting a female.)#
Veiled creatures you control get +3/+1.
Whenever a veiled creature dies, choose one — you may gain life equal to that creature’s mana value; or draw a card.
flavor: In the long winter, some curses don’t kill the body. They edit the person.
lore: The White Veil is spoken of in the same voice as hunger and plague: not dramatic, just inevitable. Some blame the Rimewind’s experiments, others whisper it’s fallout from planeswalker magics—too much power passing too near the world, fraying the weave. Whatever its source, it follows women with unsettling intimacy, as if it recognizes a particular kind of resilience and wants to test it. When the Veil takes hold, it strips secrets from witnesses and leaves its chosen moving sharper, stronger, and harder to forget.
art: A line of Veiled women advances across the snow under a full moon, steel and confidence moving as one—fierce, athletic, and unbowed. Wind tugs at hair and skirts, but nothing breaks their rhythm; their presence reads like a vow made physical. The moonlight turns them into a living emblem—beauty with determination, and discipline sharpened by winter.

name: The World Spell
rules:
The World Spell can’t be discarded, countered, destroyed, exiled, or controlled by an opponent.
When The World Spell enters play, exile all permanents. Then each player draws five basic land cards and puts them into play tapped.
{Tn}, Discard your hand: Draw that many cards.
{Ws}{Ws}{Gs}{Gs}{Gs}{Gs}, {Tn}, Sacrifice The World Spell: Exile X permanents. For each permanent exiled this way, put a card from your hand into play.
flavor: The world remembered itself—and winter had to negotiate with truth.
lore: The World Spell was not a gentle springtime prayer—it was controlled devastation aimed at freeing an entire world. Freyalise built her cauldron in the image of the Golgothian Sylex, then used Jodah’s mirror to force Terisiare to recognize itself beneath the ice. The surge should have been ruin on the scale of the Sylex Blast, but Jodah bled it outward through the Safe Havens, sacrificing them to spare the land. The Shard broke, the Thaw began, and every later attempt—Heidar’s most of all—was merely trying to argue with that new reality.
art: Green radiance pours from a cauldron’s basin in a twisting column, painting the snow with living color that doesn’t belong to winter. Freyalise’s stance is composed, almost intimate—hands guiding a force that could shatter continents if it flinched. The distant peaks read like witnesses to a verdict being delivered.

name: Toothlicker Harj
flavor: “If you’re still standing after the first swing, you’re doing it wrong.”
lore: Harj was an orcish captain with a gift for brutal clarity and a tongue sharpened on bad logistics. He’d promise blood to the eager and complain the whole time about the mess everyone made of simple violence. Beneath the sarcasm was a commander’s instinct: end fights quickly, leave nothing that can rise again, and make fear do half the work. The nickname stuck because Harj never let a victory go to waste.
art: Harj charges through snow with a hooked axe and a predator’s posture—massive shoulders, ragged furs, and a roar that sounds like an ultimatum. The moon behind him turns the moment into legend, but his face keeps it grounded: this is work, and he’s clocked in. The stance says “first strike” before you even read the card.

name: Ukoten, Centaur Chieftain
rules:
{Vigilance}`Vigilance`  {Reach}`Reach`  {Lifelink}`Lifelink`
Nonsnow creatures you control get +1/+1 as long as there’s a snow land in play.
Whenever a snow permanent an opponent controls becomes tapped, untap Ukoten and it deals 3 damage to that player.
{Xs}, {Tn}: Destroy target creature with flying where X equals its toughness.
flavor: “If the snow moves with purpose, it’s not weather—it’s a message.”
lore: The centaur chieftain learned to read the difference between winter’s rage and winter’s instruction. Near Rimewind Keep, the drifts didn’t merely shift—they obeyed, as if an unseen will had tugged the slope at the perfect moment. Ukoten’s people began to camp with spears outward and ears open, guarding against what flew above and what slept beneath the snow. To him, the greatest threat wasn’t the cold—it was the mind that could aim it.
art: Ukoten strides the pass with a chieftain’s calm, cloak and mane whipping behind him as if the mountains are testing his balance. His scars and strong features feel earned, and the paired weapons suggest a leader who hunts threats from every direction. The scene carries a quiet certainty: he knows which disasters are lies.

name: Urza's Secret Journal
rules:
{4s}, {Tn}, Return a creature you control to your hand: Look at the top five cards of your library. You may choose a creature card among them and put it into play. Put the other cards on the bottom of your library.
{2s}, {Tn}: Return target creature to its owner’s hand. If you do, scry 2.
flavor: Urza didn’t keep secrets—he kept weapons that looked like handwriting.
lore: Urza wrote as if reality were negotiable, and his Journal preserves that habit in cold permanence. The pages describe the anatomy of calling—how a will becomes form, and how form can be folded back into absence. Those who study it learn a dangerous comfort: the battlefield is not a place, it’s a draft that can be edited.
art: The Journal sits on a low stand amid broken pillars, pages spread wide as if the ink is still warm. A ribbon of blue-white force lifts from the text, shaping itself into a thought before it becomes a thing. It feels like the moment between decision and manifestation—where a single word can still send everything back.

name: Valley of the Chimes
flavor: When the chimes sang, even footprints forgot where they were going.
lore: Behind Mount Sarraza, the elves of the Chimes lived under a living ward: gigantic standing chimes whose low hum became a glowing barrier against intruders. Samor the Collector later learned their frequency could be braided into song-magic—strong enough to banish the Beast of the Hours if it ever stirred, but only by stressing the chimes themselves. Ages later, Ogwater Rifkin used that very song to loose and banish the creature, and the chimes shattered under the strain, leaving the valley intact but suddenly unguarded.
art: A long, snow-laden valley opens between black cliffs, pines clinging to the slopes like sparse stitches. The air feels tuned—too still, too listening—as if sound itself is part of the terrain. Far off, the light in the pass suggests a threshold: a place that once rang with protection, now holding its breath.

name: Vannemir of Valharad
rules:
{Vigilance}`Vigilance`  {Lifelink}`Lifelink`
Whenever a creature you control dies, you may move all counters from it to Vannemir.
{Ss}: Vannemir gains shadow until end of turn.
{Ws}{Bs}{Ss}: If Vannemir is in your graveyard, return him to play with a +1/+1 counter.
{Rs}{Ws}{Bs}: Remove target blocking creature with power 3 or less from combat.
flavor: “I don’t fear the grave. I’ve been there. It’s the living who still surprise me.”
lore: Vannemir fell defending his village from orc raiders—then rose again at the call of the valkyrie Ysidra. Bound to his Runeblade, a fylgja named Isa walked with him, mending wounds that should’ve ended him twice. With Taaveti’s guidance and Pik’s hard-won clues, he strode into Guldark’s camp, cut down warlord and shaman alike, and left Terisiare with a fighting chance against Heidar.
art: Vannemir stands on a dead-white ridge, cloak torn like a banner that refuses to fall. His Runeblade catches a faint inner sheen—too clean for iron, too calm for sorcery. The pose reads less like readiness and more like inevitability: a man returned to the world for one final crossing.

name: Vannemir's Runeblade
flavor: Vannemir’s borrowed heartbeat needed a witness. Isa chose steel.
lore: Ysidra raised Vannemir for a single road, then bound a fylgja named Isa to his Runeblade to keep him walking. The spirit’s vow turned fatal blows into setbacks and lent his strikes a merciful edge when mercy was possible. When the duty is finally paid, the blade remembers every name it couldn’t save.
art: The Runeblade rests in a wind-scoured drift, its ornate guard and etched fuller too deliberate for a lost weapon. The sky is bruised with dusk; the snow around it is undisturbed, like the world is giving it space. A faint inner sheen suggests something awake inside.

name: Varchild, Betrayer of Kjeldor
rules:
{Menace}`Menace`  {ProtectionW}`Protection from white`
Whenever Varchild deals combat damage to a player, you lose 1 life.
Whenever a creature an opponent controls deals damage to you, draw a card.
Whenever an opponent declares attackers, you may choose one of them. That player sacrifices that creature.
flavor: “I defended a king once. I won’t make that mistake again.”
lore: Varchild became the first true general Kjeldor had seen in generations, forged in loss and disciplined in ambition. She broke the Knights of Stromgald’s treachery, marched beside Balduvians against Lim-Dûl, and earned a nation’s praise. But during the Thaw, she faked her death in the mountain passes to be reborn as something Kjeldor could no longer command.
art: Varchild rides the pass in worn plate and a storm-red cloak, posture perfectly still against the wind. Frost clings to her lashes, cheekbones sharp as cut stone—she looks less like a raider and more like an order being delivered.

name: Vram, the Dobehma
rules:
+1: Target player mills three cards. For each land milled this way, you may gain 2 life and return a card from your graveyard to your hand.
-3: Destroy target land. Its controller reveals their hand. You may choose a land card from it. If you do, that player discards that land.
-8: Destroy all Swamps and black permanents. For as long as Vram, the Dobehma is in play, all lands produce colorless mana.
flavor: “Seasons are just doors. I keep the keys—and I don’t knock.”
lore: Born in Sarpadia among the Dobéhma—women who wear lilac hair like a banner and treat seasons as pliable things—Vram wandered to Peter Langwynd’s wild studies with a single practical request: a great swamp frog for her private wars. An ambush by a rival walker turned bargaining into catastrophe, and Foulmere Swamp answered her panic with a blast that tore reality sideways. In the ricochet she vanished, leaving behind her “cat” Mao—no pet at all, but her daughter bound in a shapeshifting spell.
art: Vram stands framed by a pale, round radiance like a halo of stolen seasonlight, her lilac hair whipping outward in elegant, untamed ribbons. Her posture is calm and commanding—soft curves under a fitted bodice, eyes lifted with mature certainty—like she’s inviting the world to step closer and dare it to flinch.

name: Wall of Basalt
rules:
{Defender}`Defender`  {Wither}`Wither`
Whenever Wall of Basalt blocks a creature, put a -1/-1 counter on that creature for each snow land you control.
{1s}{Bs}, Sacrifice a snow land: Return Wall of Basalt from your graveyard to play tapped, with a +1/+1 counter for each time it died this game so far.

name: Wall of Frosted Quartz
rules:
{Defender}`Defender`  {HexproofS}`Hexproof from snow`
#Snow landfall# — Whenever a snow land enters play, you may exile target creature that attacked this or last turn.
Prevent all damage that would be dealt to Wall of Frosted Quartz. When it leaves play, return all creatures exiled with it to play under your control.

name: Wall of Ice Crystals
rules:
{Defender}`Defender`  {Reach}`Reach`
#Snow landfall# — Whenever a snow land enters play, Wall of Ice Crystals loses defender and gains flying until end of turn, and you may scry 1.
Wall of Ice Crystals gets +1/+1 for each snow land you control and has landwalk of all basic land types in play.

name: Wall of Resinwood
rules:
{Defender}`Defender`  {ProtectionR}`Protection from red`
#Snow landfall# — Whenever a snow land enters play, put a +1/+1 counter on Wall of Resinwood and you gain 3 life.
{Gs}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from target creature: Wall of Resinwood loses defender and gains trample and landwalk of your choice until end of turn.

name: Wall of Scoria
rules:
{Defender}`Defender`  {Haste}`Haste`
Wall of Scoria can’t be blocked except by Walls. Whenever it blocks or becomes blocked, it deals 3 damage to any target.
Whenever you cast a snow spell, Wall of Scoria loses defender and gets +X/+X until end of turn where X equals 1 plus that spell’s mana value.

name: Water Sapphire
rules:
Basic lands you control are snow and they produce {Us} in addition to the mana they usually produce.
{2s}, {Tn}: Put a scarcity counter on Water Sapphire, then distribute X -1/-1 counters among any target creatures, where X equals the number of scarcity counters on Water Sapphire.
flavor: It doesn’t shine so much as breathe—blue to violet to pallid dawn, as if the world is drinking from it.
lore: Deep within the Water Sapphire, light behaves like water: it pools, it swirls, it changes shade when called upon, from abyssal blue to bruised violet to the pale sheen of fresh ice. Drufalden named it, and the riverking Wiggulf wielded it, not as ornament but as living doctrine—healing, shaping, animating the cold into obedient forms. Later, Og’s life-magic leaned on that same quiet depth, turning catastrophe into recovery with a glow that felt like the world choosing to continue.
art: A rough halo of frozen stone frames a sunlike gleam, the way a river might curve around an unmovable truth—Wiggulf’s kind of symbolism, carved by patience rather than hands. The glow inside the arch is warm yet unmistakably aquatic, implying water’s life-magic hiding inside ice’s discipline.

name: Wiggulf, Selkies Waterking
rules:
{Vigilance}`Vigilance`  {Islandwalk}`Islandwalk`  {Hexproof}`Hexproof`
#Landfall# — Whenever a land enters play, you may return target snow or artifact card from your graveyard to your hand.
Whenever you cast a blue or green spell, or play a Forest or an Island, you may tap or untap up to two permanents.
{1s}{Gs}{Us}, {Tn}: Counter target spell.
flavor: “Drufalden freezes borders. Rotapan poisons roads. I rule what still moves.”
lore: Wiggulf rose from the depths as riverking, a Selkie Merfolk shapeshifter crowned by currents rather than iron, and his people learned to trust the water more than the land. When Rotapan’s poison and schemes crept toward the Silver Sea, Wiggulf turned the sea itself into refuge and weapon, slipping through coasts where armies couldn’t follow. He became a wary ally to Ogwater and the song-mages, lending sanctuary, counsel, and a king’s patience.
art: Wiggulf stands waist-deep in icy water like it’s a throne that refuses to be built, his lean, regal frame marked by the quiet confidence of a ruler who doesn’t need armor. A small gleam near his raised hand reads like a relic’s promise—subtle, controlled—while pale light crowns him as if the sea itself is choosing sides.

name: Yavimaya Forest
flavor: Even in the Ice Age, Yavimaya kept a green secret—and punished anyone who tried to steal it.
lore: Yavimaya’s Ice Age face was not the gentle cradle singers imagine—it was a vast, crowded ecosystem, thick with undergrowth, bark-terraced villages, hidden falls, and roots like coiled muscle beneath the snowline. Multani’s shadow lay over it even then, and the forest’s boundaries shifted in ways maps couldn’t hold, driving out the careless and confusing the hungry. Where the world’s cold tried to erase motion, Yavimaya kept rivers running under green cover, feeding life quietly and defending it loudly.
art: This is Yavimaya in Ice Age restraint: conifers standing like sentries, snow piled high, and a ribbon of open water that feels almost defiant. The scene suggests a refuge that survives by secrecy—green pressed beneath white, movement preserved under canopy and cliff.

name: Ysidra, Valkyrie of Valor
rules:
{Flying}`Flying`  {Vigilance}`Vigilance`  {Lifelink}`Lifelink`
As Ysidra enters play, each player sacrifices a creature of your choice.
Whenever a creature you control dies, you may pay {Ws} to exile it instead. If you do, return it to play at the next end step with a +1/+1 counter.
flavor: “I don’t raise heroes. I just return debts.”
lore: In the high, bitter reaches of Adarkar, Ysidra watches the lines where hope thins and duty hardens. When Vannemir fell, she healed wounds older than that last battle—restoring strength, not comfort—and placed a mission in his hands like a blade turned toward tomorrow. She spoke of Kjeld’s fall, King Darien’s death, and the world buried under Heidar’s madness, not to frighten him, but to make refusal impossible.
art: Ysidra stands in the storm like a living vow—wings flared in shimmering authority, crown-spines of light rising from her hair as if the heavens themselves are bristling. Her beauty is fierce and mature, a calm sensual presence wrapped in steel and silk, and the blade in her hand looks less like a weapon than a final decision. The world around her feels small, and she knows it.

name: Zaraya, Kjeldoran Commander
rules:
{FirstStrike}`First strike`  {Horsemanship}`Horsemanship`
When Zaraya enters play, you may destroy target tapped creature and draw a card.
{Ws}, {Tn}: Prevent all damage that would be dealt to creatures you control this turn.
At your end step, if you control six non-animal legendary creatures and/or planeswalkers, you win the game.
flavor: “If your hands are shaking, hold the reins tighter. The dead don’t wait for courage.”
lore: Zaraya’s legend is not built on triumph, but on endurance: a commander who carried loss in silence and kept riding anyway. When Balduvia’s Marked Ones were pressed by Lim-Dûl’s minions, she gathered a small, trusted company and met the dead with steel and discipline. In the wake of war, she placed the Nova Pentacle into Freyalise’s hands, a relic offered not for glory, but for the world’s survival.
art: The scene frames her as Kjeldor’s kind of heroine: not ornate, not theatrical—just unmistakably in command. Her hair and cloak whip in the wind, but her seat in the saddle is unshaken, the horse’s stride matched to her intent. The glow behind her feels like the echo of vows spoken to the dead and kept among the living.

name: Beast of the Hours
flavor: Sealed beneath Sarraza for so long, it made even the glaciers feel temporary.
lore: During the Ice Age, Sarraza’s slopes became a white silence, and the knowledge of the Armageddon Clock faded into superstition and half-remembered warnings. Travelers spoke of unnatural pauses in the wind and a weight in the air near the mountain—as if the world were listening for a song nobody still knew. The Beast of the Hours remained locked away, not by vigilance but by ignorance: Sumifa was gone, Samor’s chronoclave was lost, and no living voice could find the binding’s seams. In that era, the cold didn’t solve the problem—it merely kept the lid on.
art: The Beast hangs over a frozen rise like a nightmare that winter failed to smother—black feathers drinking the light, ember-red wings flared against a pale, cold sky. Snow swirls around it, but the creature looks untouched by the season, as if it’s older than the Ice Age and simply wearing it as scenery. The glow behind it reads like distant fire or aurora—an omen that the seal under Sarraza is not as final as the world pretends.

name: Lord Chelydrus
flavor: The Silver Sea keeps old gods the way orcs keep trophies: wet, hungry, and very hard to argue with.
lore: Chelydrus was never a symbol to Rotapan—it was a patron, a threat, and a guarantee that fear would always have teeth. From Wyrvil’s southern edge, Rotapan ruled long past an orc’s usual years, undefeated, because he convinced others the sea-drake watched his back. Then the world changed: Drufalden’s cold broke, the waters surged, and the bone palace drowned. Chelydrus met Rotapan in the ruin like a deity returning to claim its name spoken too often.
art: Chelydrus hangs above the waves like living doom: scaled length coiled in the air, jaws wide enough to make ships feel like snacks. The ocean’s whitecaps look whipped into frenzy by its ascent, as if the sea is part of its body and not merely its home. Everything about it suggests Rotapan’s favorite kind of divinity—one that doesn’t negotiate.

name: Marit Lage
flavor: The Ronom Glacier didn’t imprison her. It merely muffled her dreams.
lore: Before the Ice Age had even finished learning its own cruelty, Marit Lage had already been entombed—sealed in a vast crypt beneath the sea, deep within the Ronom Glacier. Her power was great enough to bend legends around her name. While Terisiare froze above, she lay below in black stillness, a demigod-thing that could cross worlds yet somehow remained bound by ice, depth, and dread. When Freyalise’s World Spell later cracked the age of winter and the flooding began, the glacier’s melting should have been a release—yet the Thaw passed without her rising, leaving only the most Dominarian mystery: where did the nightmare go?
art: A colossal, kraken-like silhouette rises at the boundary of sea and sky, tentacles unfurling like slow thoughts surfacing from a centuries-long dream. The waterline cuts the image like a lid being lifted—black depth below, cold air above—hinting at the Ronom Glacier’s buried crypt without showing it. Those dim, ember eyes feel unhurried: not rage, not hunger—just inevitability.

name: Rhindle, the Scaled Wurm
flavor: The snow made Rhindle beautiful. The teeth made it honest. Its size made it inevitability.
lore: The Ice Age made monsters more patient, not less, and Rhindle embodied that quiet, coiled endurance. It lived within Fyndhorn’s depths yet pressed the border near Jornstad, testing the city like a tooth tests bone. When Finroy played at heroism in Rothchild’s guise, Rhindle attacked at the edge of town, leaving only a broken bones and shaken prides in its wake.
art: Rhindle rears from the snow like a living mountain—scaled coils piled thick, head lifted in a roar that seems to shake the treeline. His green body reads as ice-hardened muscle under armor, and the winter field around him feels suddenly fragile, as if the land itself has realized it’s outmatched. The distant woods suggest Fyndhorn’s claim: this is not a visitor, it’s a border that moves.

name: Valthus the Leviathan
flavor: The Golthonor Sea doesn’t do ‘warnings.’ It has Valthus.
lore: Valthus haunted the Golthonor Sea like a living siege engine—Segovian scale, Dominarian malice, and a will as deep as the trenches it slept in. When Jared Carthalion sought the second long-dagger beneath those waters, Grenfell Mor tried to end the story early by unleashing Valthus on him. The leviathan rose as the sea’s chosen executioner, jaws wide enough to make anyone’s bravery look small...
art: Valthus bursts from churning water like a weapon drawn from a sheath—massive blue hide, spined ridges, and a mouth full of verdict. The storm around him feels less like weather and more like the Golthonor Sea reacting to its own guardian waking. He looks commanded, not summoned: a familiar terror doing a practiced job.
